Samuel W. F. Bangor, Oct 13 1856
Bangor Oct 13th 1856
Dear Mother
I suppose you like to hear often from us if we have nothing to say. We are I think, all well, most certainly I am, Irving cries most of the time when awake I think his teeth trouble him some and he very much need a little "wholesome neglect" pity he cant have it. Have not heard from Issac since you left. The Roman Catholic Cathedral was consecrated yesterday a great day for the Irish. Mr. Tebbets commenced to finish off two chambers today, he hopes to get them plastered this week. he does them by the job. does the work and furnishes all material for $52.45. with what a different feeling I take hold to do any thing about the house now from what I have ever done before. I do it now because I know it ought to be done. it gives me no pleasure, my heart

is not in it as it was and should be in every thing which goes to make home pleasant and convenient. I know that instead of mourning over my present lot I ought, to give thanks for the many happy days which have been mine, the memory of which will ever be blessed Oh that my tongue or my pen might be unloosed that I might make known all that is burning within me. it seems to me that I have been denied the power of telling all that I would more than most are able to do, and I suppose I must learn more to show by deeds and actions what I would wish to express so I will make no further effort to express thoughts or feelings to night I have taken the place of a boarder this week. my feelings are at times almost beyond control, but a sense of duty has so far sustained me and I trust that will continue to.
To Percie. Father wants to see you very much. and he wants you to be a very good boy. always mind what what Grandmother

or Uncle Charles or Aunt Albina tell you always mind very quick, and always be very kind to Mary when you play with her and perhaps one of these days father will come up to Milo and bring you and Grandmother home with him because father wishes very much to have you and Grandmother here with him, and want you to be glad when father comes after you, and father will be glad if Grandmother tells me that my little Percie has been a good boy and now my boy good night may God watch over you while you are asleep and protect you, and you will learn to love God who is so good to you.
S.W. Furber

Elyria April 13th 1857
Dear Mother
I suppose you would like to see my hand writing by the time this will reach you. you will see by what I've wrote Eliab about how I am getting along, I read a letter recd by Anna from you the day I reached here. you of course must be a practical judge of some things or persons upon which you give an opinion, if you knew all that I know I dont see how you could write as you do, it is a great comfort to me to know that you love and esteem me. I only wish that I could more than I do merit that esteem and love, if I could find words how gladly would I express to you the deep love and gratitude which I bear to you. May heaven bless you. How much I want to see Percie. yet I feel that it is best that he is with you. tell that father sends him a great deal of love and wants him to be a good boy. and I will write him a letter when I get to Minnesota. I have been spending the time here very pleasantly between the

two houses. I stay nights at Anna's we read some. talk some, try to sing at times but often have to stop and cry, I hope to hear from you often With much love to all, yours affectionately S.W. Furber
S.W. Furber
Elyria April 13th '57 Bangor
Sam  Elyria April 13 /57

S.W. Furber Elyria April 20 '57 Bangor
Elyria April 20th 1857
Dear Mother
Tis a beautiful morning, how fresh and invigorating, I returned here from Brookville Saturday evening, I had a very pleasant trip then. although the road beyond Kittanning was abundantly bad. 44 miles by mud cart, time seventeen hours fro 10 AM to 3 AM the road in places on the Crows of Mills. with the outer wheels within eighteen inches of the edge of precipices seven hundred feet in heighth and no protection to keep the carriage in the road. riding in such places in a dark night with out any light and the driver filled with bad whiskey is not very conducive to sleep. How ever I've been and returned all safe, There is much in travelling through such a country to awaken thought and deep feeling and high asperations. I should think that the poetry and the music of one living in such a place must possess

an elevation of thought and character beyond the reach of one whose life is confined to narrower spheres of polished halls
I was very much interested yesterday in two meetings held here by Mr Van Metre of the five points Mission school, who is looking up homes for children he had three little boys here, he gave an account of their operations, and presented the claims of these destitute children in a simple, clean and most affecting manner. the sympathies of all were arroused and few could listin to him with dry eyes. I think it is good to have our sympathies thus wrought upon, so that we may be led to say
"O give me tears for others woe And patience for my own"
The weather here is very cold it has snowed almost every day for a week past untill to day I do not think it is any more

forward here than in Bangor. the grass is beginning to look green, but no leaves to be seen. Ice is yet in Lake Pepin I shall leave here Wednesday, stop one day in Chicago and over the sabbath with a cousin in Northern Ill. (Nancy Wingate) and probably get to St Paul about the last day of this month. I have been very well since I left, am now wanting very much to hear from you and Percie and all the others at Bangor, please write often and let me know all about Percie. Every thing in relation to him will possess a great interist to me it seems to me that no one else can know how I wish to know every thing which relates to him to know and to feel that he will have the best care taken of him and be subject to the best possible influences, will not lessen my desire to know all about him, and for this I must depend almost entirely upon

you, and I know that you will find much satisfaction in giving me this information
Enclosed I send you a copy of a peice from the Era, it seems to be very beautiful and truthful.
To me, the thought, that our dear Lucy has given a direction to Percie's character and impulses which will ever go with him to the end of life is very dear, I may say almost sacred I trust I might improve every present opportunity for doing good, and not throw upon the future what belongs to the present, not knowing that there will be for me, in time, any other than the present, Ask Percie when he says his prayers at night if he will not ask God to bless father, tell him that father asks God to take care of him every day. Much love to all
S.W. Furber

April 21st. Not having sent my letter last evening I open it this morning to add to it. This village was thrown into a state of much excitement yesterday by an incident upon the Pearl Road. The train due here from Cleveland about five P.M. ran over a cow at the East End of the East Bridge mutually knocking each other from the track. The Engine left the track as it went upon the bridge (the track is upon the top of the Bridge as at Kendalls Mills) the bridge is forty feet above the water and about 150 ft in length, there were two baggage cars one 2nd Class and the other 1st Class Cars, the Engine went over the bridge off the track and leaped from the abutment down the bank as it left the bridge the tender following it, the baggage cars went past the Engine and then down the bank, the near end of the second one stopping near the top of the bank the forward end of the 2nd Class

car resting upon it and the near end upon the road, the three first class cars stoping on there bridge with track torn all up under the forward one.
Two Engine men and a fireman on the Engine and tender and one or two were in the baggage cars
Not one person has been seriously injured, To stand and look upon the bridge with the torn track and broken floor upon the Engine and cars as they were last evening and know that no life was lost, no one dangerously injured, seems almost miraculous. It certainly calls for devout gratitude to God. 
How different might have been the scene. This morning the road is cleared, the track relaid and trains have passed over the bridge, which seems about as strange as the events of yesterday
Good bye
SWF

St Paul May 15th 1857
Dear Mother
Your letter of April 27 I see today on my return from Cottage Grove. I arrived here the first day of the month at 6:30 A.M. I left Elyria on Wednesday April 25th one day to Chicago. Stopped their one day. Spent a night with Mr & Mrs Cha's Thaxter who were quite glad to see me, and I was glad to see Lizzie. I think that she is not very happy, and no one to blame but herself. She believes it is quite an act to learn to be content. Chicago I dislike very much. Flat and wet, I stopped a few days with Fred Wingate in DuPage County 20 miles West from Chicago, a very fine country.  The prairie is much more rolling than I had thought, unimproved land is worth then $25 to 30 per acre wood enough if evenly distributed good water by digging 20 feet. Some of the country between them and Dunleith is flat and undesirable. I arrived at Dunleith Monday eve April 27

went directly aboard of a steamer for St. Paul. Fare $7.00 arrived at Lake Pepin Wednesday Eve April 29. Ice not out of the lake.Some 20 Boats waiting. Our boat the WS Nelson went into the ice and worked all night. Breaking ice to the great discomfort of nervous passengers. I enjoyed it much. Something to break the monotony of Steamboat life. Thursday morning we were joined by other Boats got through the lake at night and arrived at St. Paul at 6:30 A.M May 1st. I had a cold through all my journey and the day we got to Lake Pepin I was almost sick. laid in my berth all day , but watching the breaking of ice that night got me well, and have felt nicely all the time since. The scenery on the river is intensely beautiful and grand, evidently the design of a great architect.
I find my folks here all but Theodore for whom I have many fears. I went to Cottage Grove May 2 and came back here yesterday. You can probably judge better

than I can tell how I spent my time. 
Sometimes, often, we anticipate in the meeting of long absent ones more than we seem to realize, but with you I can say in all truth that I have enjoyed their day with great satisfaction, and not the least of my enjoyment have I found in the children. They so much love which we feel to be pure, I had not thought of it. I presume you wish to know how I like Minnesota, I like it well. The farming country about Cottage Grove is certainly very fine, there are some objections. Great ones, a scarcity of wood and water, as to wood the objection is not great, as a plenty of it can be got by drawing a few miles. There are many little ponds which afford a great supply of water. But locally cannot be got less than from 100 to any unknown number of feet. They use storm and cement cisterns to get water for drinking. The land is excellent fully meeting my expectations.
I have not yet decided on anything for permanent business. Father will start East about the middle of June. do not

know how long he may stay. Oliver and Mr. Haskell were intending to go East in the fall. I shall make arrangements with some of them to accompany to Elyria, if you have no other opportunity. The Legislature has now been in session three weeks trying to dispose of the lands granted by Congress to this Terr(itory) for building  R. Roads they have made but little progress.
I hope to get a chance for Isaac some of these projected rail Roads. 
I know you will write me often.
Tell Percie that father wants very much to see him and hopes he will be a good boy.
Much love to all.
S.W. Furber
St. Paul May 15th '57

S.W. Furber
St. Paul May 1857
May 25th 1857
Dear Mother:
It has been a rainy day. It is a rainy evening. Father is gone out as usual and I am almost lonesome. I did not know but you would like to see a plan of my present home and I have drawn a rough sketch. The rooms No from 1 to 5 are rented $180 per year. The others Father occupies, I do not think it a very convenient house. There is no chamber in the house, no clothes press, no place to store away anything. I shall have to send most of my things to Cottage Grove when they come. I can put one Bureau and sink in my room and crowed in the old Secretary too, perhaps I may. I have been back from the Grove 10 days. Have been out of town 3 days looking about. Should have

been away today if it had not rained. I expect to go in a few days to Crow Wing 120 miles up the river. I have the offer of one third of a town of 320 acres laid out for a village consisting of 1407 lots for about $1300. If I like the looks of it I may buy and settle up there it is on the line of the R Road to Pembina and is a point to which the charter confines the road and is within 1 1/4 of the crossing of the Mississippi near 1 1/4 miles the junction of the Superior and Pembina Road. If I should go then I will let you know sometime. Unless I see something that is quite inviting before fall I think that I shall go to farming. I am satisfied that I can make a living at that business and make myself a home although it may be an humble

one, and I feel as though I wanted a place to call home, where I can have Percie with me. It is no use I cannot talk fast enough, cannot farm and flatten the egotism of people sufficiently to keep up in the hurry and scramble of this age. I turn from it with loathing and disgust. I had rather bring Percie up a stranger to every advantage of civilized society than that he should become an adept in the arts and practices which lead to place and preferment at this day. Every body here seems to be possessed with a spirit of adventure and speculation. little or no thought is paid to those things which go to make up the comforts and happiness of home life and fireside pleasures. I hope, the grace of God helping me, to give

my little influence for the right. Pray for me that I may be enabled to resist the evil and stand for the truth.
About Percie, I feel very glad that I did not bring him out with me. I know that he much better off with you and is probably happier than he would be here. I do not know that I can give you any advice about him, do with him all things as you think best. If I should say anything it would be, require strict obedience to your every request, but I know there is no need of my saying this. May our Heavenly Father strengthen you and guide by his wisdom in all your labor of love
Tell Percie Father sends him a kiss.
Affectionately,
S.W. Furber

Tuesday morning, May 26th/57
It is still raining. I have made a fire in the office, swept out and been to the Post Office. got "many" letters. The spring here is very backward and cold. But no more so than below, the trees are putting on a layer of green. This Western Country is not so level as I expected to see it. The prairie grass is shorter than I supposed and the prairie fires far less magnificent, in all other respects it fully comes up to my anticipation, the land is very fertile and produces abundantly all crops but hay which this soil does not seem well adapted. Hay is worth here now $50 per ton, a great deal of hay was burnt on the meadows last fall and the winter has been one of unusual

severity. a great many cattle have died from exposure and want of feed. This difficulty of growing hy is one of the disadvantages of this country. This is certainly a good place for a farmer and will be for a long time to come. The Emigration to this Territory. The Lumbering. The Mining and the Rail Roading must for many years make a home market
two years ago Theodore, after reserving what he wanted to supply his family, sold produce to the amount of $4000, from the product of less than 100 acres. Theodore came here 11 years ago last fall with about $700, he has been sick a good deal, had one years crop destroyed by fire and his house burned, and is now I should judge worth from $12,000 to $15,000, but to get this he he has worn himself out, I greatly

fear that he will be with us but a short time. he's troubled much with bronchitis and dispepsy, nd is very much debilitated. has had two attacks of diarrhea since I have been here, which at this season of the year seem to me to indicate much weakness,
Everything here seems to bear the impress of haste, there is nothing that seems to be finished. Three percent is the spirit of the age, nobody can or will use money for any other purpose when they can get from 3 to 5 percent per month for it, I settled some business for Theodore since I came here, he loaned $500 March 1st 1856, January 7th, 1857 he received on the note $100, and May 13th 1857 I collected the balance of $677.50 and still the man who hired it made money. He bought at Prescott

in the fall of 1855, 14 1/3 acres of land for $900, when he paid the note he sold 11 acres of this land for $3500. These things account for the haste there is here, and the want of attention to the little things that go to make up life. I have not become much acquainted here yet, have been introduced to but two Ladies in St. Paul and one of those last evening, a Mrs. Goodwin, who is from Racine, and was acquainted with Anna there, I think I can tell now I like the place after becoming more acquainted,. If the ladies are as much possessed of the age of 3 percent as the men are, I don't believe I shall like them.
Much love with best wishes and a promise to write again.
Samuel
S.W. Furber
St. Paul, May 27th

Boston Monday Eve June 22/57
Dear Mother
I suppose you were some surprised to receive telegraph from me from Elyria. I arrived at Newton Corner Saturday afternoon, have been to Newburyport today. I may start for Bangor and Milo tomorrow evening, but cannot say positively. I suppose you are wondering what I am here for, I am after money to buy a steam mill, but do not much expect to get it. I am disappointed in Newburyport where I most depended upon getting it. I shall look about there some more before I go to Bangor. I am very well. Stand traveling much better than when I went west. Theodore leaves St. Paul today to come here. Helen comes with him. He has improved some the last three weeks. Father does not leave until I get back. I ought to leave Bangor for the coast next Monday, as you might suppose. Isaac, Nettie & Anna are anxious for you to go back to Elyria with me. I would like much to have you go but do not wish to urge you unless you judge it best. I'm ? hoping to see you all in a few days. With much love
Samuel

S.W. Furber
St Paul July 18 57
Elyria
St. Paul. Saturday Eve July 18th 1857
Dear Mother
It has been almost three weeks since I left Elyria and I have heard nothing from any of you in all that time and I want to hear very much. I wish to know whether you got well over your journey and how you now are. also I wish to know how Percie is. and what kind of a boy he is now. I have had some fears that he might think himself of considerable importance in consequence of being noticed more than usual, and I wish to hear from you  all. My health is excellent, but I do not feel very well. for quite a number of days past I have felt unusually sad and lonesome, kind of uneasy and unsatisfied, as I become more acquainted here I hope to enjoy myself better

I have made but very few acquaintances here. Except with businessmen and those acquaintances you know do not come into Morning and Evening hours. I lodge at Father's house get my meals at a public boarding house 3/4 of a mile distant. My boarding place however is but a short distance from the office which is very convenient. Father starts next Monday the 20th for the East. he is now at Cottage Grove. The business of the office will not keep me very busy but it is necessary that I should be here most of the time as the Cemetery and Mr Poon? must be attended to on call. Last Sabbath Rev Mr Mattocks of the First Presbyterian Church forced me into the Sabbath School and Choir. he says, "we do not ask people here but just say come"

I was very willing and glad to go to both places. I have a class of 4 boys about 14 years old. Think it may be a pleasant class, in the Choir I found three Ladies. no gentleman but the organist. no choirmaster.  I've something to do here most certainly. I think that I wrote you since I got back that it was quite probable that I should go to Merrimac. Mr Cushing referred the whole matter to his brother who is his agent here and he says that cannot get along with less than $5000, so now I probably won't go there. The Constitutional Convention which met here last Monday has broken into two, which have about as much affinity for each other as water and oil. It will require an alkali to make them unite. I've sent Isaac a paper giving accounts of the proceedings

S.W. Furber
St. Paul July 2 '57 Sheet 2 -- July 20th
Elyria
I had a letter from Theodore a few days since. he does not seem to have got much relief yet. I've not heard anything from Bangor or Milo since I got back. I am reading a book called "Modern Pilgrims" by George Wood of Philadelphia. It is on the plan of Bunyan's Pilgrim's Progress. The pilgrimage is from Babylon the less (N.Y.) to the "Celestial City" via the "Interpreters House," "Vanity Fair" Some of the Characters are first Mr and Mrs Cartwright and Mr and Mrs Freeman from the Fifth Avenue. Then the Rev Dr Upatrce?. Miss Golightluy and others of Babylon. The Freemont, The Oxford the Hotel d'Italia among the Interpreter's Houses. At the Interpreter's we find the Rev Dr Dodge, Rev Mr Spearung Hopewell also among the Interpreters were some strong minded women. At Vanity Fair they

met My Lord and Lady Dickinson Colonel and Mrs Proudfitt, Lord Shallbeso and Bishop Highhandry. The family of Thurnupnoses. Farther than this I have not read. It's a very amusing if not an instruction book. If you haven't it at Elyria I will some time send you some extracts from it
Chapter 1 "As the newcomer drew near, stealthily, to the circle, he was first seen by Frank, who, rising, stretched out his hand as he spoke: "Ah my old friend Conscience! What brings you here? But first let me present you to my sweet wife, Gertrude. And here too are Oliver and his wife. You see we have followed your advice and in doing so have given hostages to society for our good behavior." And now asked Frank, I am curious to what has brought you here at this time? Have you any very libelous charge against us to our wives? You may as well tell all for I know you have an errand of some sort" "My young friends, replied the old

man in a tone of great kindness, I rejoice to know you have yourselves into the care of these ladies. -- Going to them as he spoke -- It is the first step toward safety, purity and peace. --- --- --- "O yes ! cried Annie. we are at our wits' end to know what to do next, and if you can save us from the misery we suffer I shall be glad. Our husbands love us dearly, Don't you? said she turning briskly round to Oliver, --- --- --- but dear sirs we are not able to make our husbands happy. They told us we could and we hoped we might and I'm sure we've tried to do so, haven't we, Gertrude? --- --- --- My young friends, said Conscience, listen to me, you sigh for happiness and it is not here. Wealth is yours already, and fame is hard to attained. The stimulus of necessity is wanting to success, you cannot compete with men whose intellectual strength

is brought up to its height by the promptings of poverty and it may be the claims of children. But you my friends have a crown to gain, a life to win, or a life to lose, and all depends on your being pilgrims to the Celestial City. Are you ready? --- --- ---  Dear Mr Conscience, said Gertrude, I shall be glad to go, but will not you be our guide?
Here my Lady, said Mr C-, taking a small book from his pocket, here is the Guidebook; read this. Make it the man? of your counsel. It will be of itself sufficient. Let this be the light to your path, and you need fear no evil.
Chap 5 "We shall not attempt to portray this rising of the morning star and the day dawn of the soul. The more faithfully this is done the less likely it is to be understood" --- --- --- "Mr Conscience came down and never was he so welcome as now. He listened patiently to all they had to say and sought with affectionate sympathy to calm Annie's fears as to the perils and trials of the way. For Annie did not scruple to

--- having thanked her for her politeness and saying it would give him pleasure in any way to contribute to her pleasure, he was about to add something more when Annie touched his toe with her own under the table, intimating that he had said enough, and he left off there. And here we will say that no one who has a sensable wife can be too grateful for these marital telegraphic dispatches. ---- ---- ---- --- "and yet I hate to hear anything to the disadvantage of any around me, for I never feel afterwards precisely as I did before. It takes time to wean out these ink -spots on the memory."
St. Paul July 25th 1857
Dear Mother
Above I send you a little more of the Modern Pilgrims. Enclosed I also send you a few items from The Times and its correspondent F (Flint they call him (or her) Thought I would not let so good an opportunity
on side: S.W. Furber  St Paul  July 1857   Elyria

pass unused, don't you think, he takes it kindly? a further proof of the the truth of "Returning Answers" I tell him in another communication today.
I am going to see if I cannot shame one paper at least out of its propensity to roll in the dirt. I've talked to him today with "tears in my eyes" all by letter and "income" whether it dies any good or not it has the effect of amusing me, hope it won't damage "Mr. Times" Don't know if anything especial interest at present. My health's good. Think it might improve would I hear more from you. Haven't heard a word since I left you, all well here. have not heard from Theodore since I wrote you last. Love to all and a bunch of kisses to be distributed as called for.
S.W. Furber

Page 12
I missed this page when I wrote. I thought I would copy a few words from the Modern Pilgrim and have found myself considerably drawn out. I've been a good deal interested and amused with it hope some of you will get-it for 5 Minutes, it will do you no harm. I have written in a good deal of haste and you may be somewhat puzzled to read it. It will be an experience of patience which I suppose is always good.
Much love to all. Give Percie a number of kisses for me, tell him grandfather is coming to see him
Yours
S.W. Furber

St. Paul Aug 1st 1857
Dear Mother
Isacc's of the 23rd and yours of the 24th and 7 of July reached me this morning and wasn't I glad to hear from you? I had really began to worry for fear that some of you were very sick, but am happy now to know that you are all so well. hope to keep hearing "that same", I should have enjoyed the trip to the Lake shore with you very much no doubt, I wish that it were not so far to Ohio, I have not heard from Theodore since I last wrote you, have heard but once since I came back, have heard nothing from Maine, except by Mr Jacob C. Smith whom I spent in Wis on way home. He came into the office a few days since with some scraps of Bangor items, it appears that a daughter of A.M. Roberts, another of Dr Rich who died a few years since, both of them Granddaughters of old Dr Rich and the second daughter of Tho's A. White have been courting the boys a little too fast, and as old Socabeson? said are -- "very sorry on't" "a'la Worcester", isn't Bangor smart?
I don't know of anything at present that would be of particular interest to you. Our two Constitutional Conventions are each building a Constitution, if with these they will give the

new state two back bones. They would do good service. What will be the result of these proceedings time alone, the great revealer, will show. Although to my mind the "dimmecrats" are wholly wrong, I think this posture of affairs might have been avoided by the Republicans by conceding where concession would have done them no injury, like all quarrels, neither the right nor the wrong are wholly the right of either beligerant.
I am having pretty quiet times now, although I have something to do every day, as overseer of the poor for the County and have much that is amusing, some things that are provoking and annoying, and cases calling for sincere sympathy, the puzzle's now to be at all times duly amused, provoked or sympathetic, for a misapplication of either condition of mind might be a great injustice to the applicant. I have exchanged my 80 acre farm in Cottage Grove for 80 acres of timberland on the river about 15 miles below here paid $150, "to boot" The timberland now stands me about $6 per acre I hope it is worth $25. I bought 160 acres of land yesterday at Minnetonka 10 miles from Minneapolis for $4, per acre. This land is said to be worth $10. I bought it for a 13th Cousin in N.H. who left $550,

with me in the Spring to invest for him. The balance I paid. I've written him offering to take half the trade and pay him ? percent for his money. don't know what he will do and don't care very much. I yesterday took a contract to grade a street there, where there is to be an embankment estimated at 18,000 yards I got 50 cents per yard and have sublet it for 38 cents per yard. If the man does his work up in good shape I shall do very well by it. I made both contracts before breakfast yesterday morning. Our singing at the Presbyterian is so bad that I can hardly say that I enjoy it. We are to have a rehearsal this evening and I hope for better things tomorrow.
Much love for all, please write
S.W. Furber
For T.?S.
I think that the building and improvements of the streets in this City this season will amount to $200000, think of that for a city of 10000 people the money for opening and grading streets is not assessed upon the City Rolls but is paid by the lots, per foot without regard to value, fronting upon the streets so opened and graded, repairs, culverts and street crossing are paid from City Treasury.

S.W. Furber
St Paul. Aug 5'57
Elyria
St Paul Aug 5th 1857
Dear Mother
Enclose you will find a letter for Percie. I wished to talk with him so took this way, it may amuse him. how much I want to see him. You may also find some scribblings, sometimes I amuse myself by jotting whatever happens to occupy my mind, not of any worth to any one but might serve to while away a dull hour. Yesterday and to day I've had but little to do. been alone most of the time museing and muselen?. Tupper says, and I incline to believe it, that "Mind may act upon mind, though bodies be far divided: For the life is in the blood, but souls communicated unseen"; I wonder if it is so, and if death destroys that communion of soul? I love to think that it does not, and at times, not unfrequent, I think that there is still existing that sweet sympathy of soul with the loved and lost, very strange and undefined feelings possess me at times which  I love to account for by such a faith.
John has just been in. I had not seen any of "the folks" before for more 4 weeks. they are all well and crops looking finely We had a big fire here yesterday morning

lasting from 2 to 5 Oclock. burnt almost one entire square. there is no engine or fire department here, and if it had been in any degree windy the destruction must have been very great. The fire was stoped only by tearing down two buildings, and although there were men enough yet without any acknowledged leader they worked to much disadvantage. I am not much hoarse today, but my arms feel somewhat still and it seems my face yet burns from the heat of the fire. The buildings burned were all wooden ones and I suppose the fire may be considered as a kind of necessary evil, resulting in the end in a public benefit, loss estimated from $35000 to $50,000 my contracts for grading 7th Street are all made and subcontract, and I can see nothing why I may not realize some $ 4000, without any investment in liability, I've just rec a letter from Mr Cushing still wishing me to go to Merrimac. don't know about it, if I could have had the same offer one month ago I could have gone, now it is indifferent. he will be here soon when I can tell more Much love S.W.Furber
vertical writing follows
all "the folk" at Elyria may read, if they wish, my letters to you. if they will answer. I beg Ann's pardon for writing in the margin

Samuel W. Furber
St Paul Aug 14 57
Elyria
St Paul Aug 14th 1857
Dear Mother
Yours of July 30th & Aug 7th are rec It is a very great comfort to me to receive your letters & know that you are all well, but value them most for the counsels which they contain. I thank you very much that you are willing to advise and caution me. I hope you will keep on doing just so and I will try to remember the things you tell me. Many, very many are snares and temptations which surround one here, and many are they which fall into them, in respect to some of them, the more gross? and sensual which count their victims by thousands I am fortunate. They are not temptations to me. it requires no effort to shun them, but without doubt they are many temptations here for all and those which are the most dangerous

are those which we least suspect, which come in the fairest forms. and lead away from a christian life before we are aware of their influence. perhaps my greatest danger is that the excitement of business would lead me away from the exercise of religous that's? I suppose the only safety is in a continual watch, and reliance upon divine help, I have felt in days past that there was a special providence watching over me to protect me in answer to special prayers in my behalf, and may I not still have a consciousnes of such protection in behalf of prayers offered for me? I know I may, There is one evil against which you caution me that does not happen to exist. "compliments & flateries" There's no danger here, in fact I don't receive quite so many as would be pleasant, is'nt that a confession? Of course you will present my heartiest congratulations to Isaac and Nettie. hope their quiver will be filled with arrows,

I think, myself that the "Times" has not suffered at all by a few suggestions and nubs which they have occasionally recd I send you to day, paper, which contains quite an article for professing christians to think of. I have recd letters from Theodore, Hellen and Father, Theodore's health does not seem to be improving as we would wish. Father writes that all the Physicians whom he has consulted pneumonia his lungs sound. and his disease to be debility from dyspepsia and excessive labor?. he thinks of starting home the first of Sept. I've had no letter from Bangor Mile or Brownville, I have been writing a letter to Prof Shepard and will copy a few things from it
"A few days since my domestic happiness and my temporal welfare were all that I desired. in the first my cup was running o'er and I had a sufficiency of this worlds goods for my own wants, and something to releive the wants of others. Few, very few, have ever been as blessed as I in their domestic life, The sun, whose shining was all the

warmth and light of that life, has set, and how bright its sitting. How the remembrance of that sunset glow will ever be impressed upon us all who beheld it. to cheer, to sooth, to encourage, we know what gave it is splendor, and may we not, amid the choking cares of life, forget it, if we wish that ours might be like it, _ _ _ never shall I forget or cease to be grateful for your kind attention and your warm sympathy. from my heart I thank you. I thank you for myself, and for her to whom your calls were ever looked for with an earnest desire and to whom they were a source of much comfort _ _ _ does the knowledge that there is bread fill the hungrey? or the fact that there is rain in the clouds water the parched Earth? Neither does the so suspicion that there is sympathy somewhere cheer the sad and bruised spirit. _ _ _ but may then not be those among you. shivering under the chilling influences of such frosty sympathies, who might by the warmth of christian love be made blessings to you?" Much Love S.W.Furber

S.W. Furber St Paul, Aug 26 1857 Elysia
St. Paul Aug 26th 1857
Dear Mother:
How much I would love to be with you today, and most likely if were I would sit and say nothing, if we can silence the tongue. we cannot still thought. it seems so just and good to look back that I sometimes fear that I look too much in that direction, not looking forward and up enough. There is so much that is repulsive in the world that I shrink from contact with it and I expect to an extent that is wrong, lest how can I help it when almost every such contact gives pain, I sometimes wish that I was made of material not so sensitive, what's the use of it? Those less sensitive have less annoyances and perhaps may do none good, although possible may not be capable of enjoying in so high a degree, How is it: should we try to cure ourselves of the grating which mice makes, when it runs its fingers over the chords of the soul? Or can we if we would? As I said to a friend in a letter a few days since

"you will all understand that it is not in me to trim my thoughts in a manner of expressing them, you will get them just as they are dug up without polish and I hope hope without alloy," This I suppose you already understood and are willing to make all allowances for my interjectory manner, I cannot connect and smooth up anything. Enclosed you will find some of morning's waste of time perhaps to all but myself. I rec a few days since a Boston Advertiser containing an abstract of an address by GG Felton, I enjoyed it much and send a few extracts from it. I have not heard from Father or Theodore since I wrote last, all are well here. My health is very good. am suffering some want of exercise which I will hunt up when Father gets back. If I should have to go to Ohio for it, I want to see Percie.
With a great deal of love  yours
Samuel
I'd like to see some of Anna's marks

Aug 26th 1857
"Better is the day of one's death than the day of their birth",
We suppose this must be true, but how hard to believe. It is one of those things which we can believe only by the exercise of faith, we believe it because God has declared it, to reason and human conception it could never be made to appear. We rejoice at the birth which it is all unknown as to the future whether the life just commenced shall be this or that, an endless duration of bliss or woe, and none even question the propriety of such rejoicing. But who ever thought of commemorating the anniversary of ones' death with rejoicing? How is this? Can you explain it? How much of late have my thoughts been with the past, living over again the years that have gone. And I feel that it is good for me this day to call to mind the character of our beloved Lucy. But how can I speak of men on what can I say, any attempt to set forth new worth would be such an utter failure that I had better keep silent. I can only say that the more I see of life in others and the more I learn of myself, the more I cherish her memory, and the more I consider her qualities of mind and heart as of very rare occurrence. Although

not what might be termed brilliant, her mind was one which would bear examination in any direction. there was no point in which it was not above a medium, and in many qualities she had but few peers, But we are held by the most magic influences when we remember her qualities of heart. I should be unwilling to admit that any one ever had greater depth on beat with a stronger pulse, and she loved her friends with all her strength, self seemed with her ever to be a second consideration. She found her happiness in ministering to that of those she loved. And the influence of such a love upon us, who can tell, how much it has had to do in quickining into life and shaping whatever there is within us of pure and earnest desire for all things which are good and true. I know that to me it has been of worth beyond price, and I thank God that I was permitted to live so long safe to the influence of such a mind and heart.
"What I do thou knowest not now, but thou shalt know hereafter"

St Paul Nov 2 1857
torn manuscript Mother
I rec a letter from you last week, while at work on the road, also from Isaac. I need not say that I am always glad to receive letters from you. I have been absent on the road 4 weeks, leave again to day shall probably be away until I compete the road. Sometime the fore part of Dec, I have but a small crew, 2 teams and 14 men, are getting along with the work very well, shall make good wages if the job. Money in St Paul is exceedingly tight. The City is issuing (unable to issue) scrip in the form of bills for its indebtedness which torn manuscript plated will pass for currency.

The work on 7th Street (my contract) has been measured, although not completed, it gives me about $2400, when I shall collect it is altogether uncertain, but it will draw 30 per cent interest until paid.
I am glad to have you write about Percie, how much I want to see him, I am glad that he likes to go to school, but do not think it well for him to be urged to study, or excited in relation to it in any way, unless he should be inclined to show an aversion to it, however I feel that you torn manuscript as well or better than I can torn manuscript to pursue with him, I know it torn manuscript that boys are not so likely to become vain of fine clothing as are girls, but when they do so become they appear much more silley and contemptable, I suppose you have have heard the anecdote of the lady who asked her Minister if he thought it an evidence of pride for a person to dress well, his reply was, "when you find a fox hole, and the fox's tail sticking out, be sure the fox is in the hole," We have been having beautifull weather for 7 or 8 weeks past, it is now beginning to feel cold, and I  fear cold weather before torn manuscript

work on the road, I do not know what I shall be about next winter, some of the folks at Cottage Grove wish me to get a place here and sell their produce for them, they can not sell it to merchants here and get their pay, and are afraid to sell on Credit. If I could get enough to do to pay expenses I might do it, but it is quite uncertain, Should I find nothing to do here for 4 or 5 months I might find my way to Ohio. Could I get boarded there? torn manuscript do you hear from Eliab? I've had torn manuscript very small letter from him torn manuscript left Bangor, although he said torn manuscript that he had written me before, If he can stand these times I guess he will get along, How are Isaacs Du Quoin matters? 
While on the road at work I have been busy and contented, but since I got back here night before last I've been anything but in good spirits. I do not know what the trouble is. I do not feel at home any where. I suppose the cure is to keep at work,
Best wishes to all
With much love
Samuel

drawing of St Paul SAINT PAUL in 1857 Engraved by J.W. Orr N.Y.
St Paul Nov 13th 1857
Dear Mother
I quit work on the road last Monday morning, reason, 10 inches of show, which fell Saturday Evening and Sunday. Winter seems to be upon us in earnest, it has really thawed but little any day this week, and my work will have to lay over untill Spring. I have about a weeks work to put in some culverts and then I shall go into winter quarters. I get on my street contract here $2471.18. my pay is in certificates of assesments upon lots on the street which creats a lien upon the property and is considered good security, which certificates draw 30 per cent interest. My Government contract amounts in all to but about $3000. I shall make good wages on that

perhaps $400. I have not decided upon anything for business the coming winter. Many farmers about Cottage Grove wish me to sell their grain and flour for them this winter, they think I should have from 40 to 50 thousand bushels of oats, corn & wheat to sell, which at a fair commission would make a good business for me, if I can find a good room without paying St Paul rents I may conclude to do it. The only reason why I do not wish to do it, is, that it will prevent my visiting Elyria, which I had almost set my heart upon, but perhaps I may steal a few days in the Spring, to go there, I want to see Percie and the rest of you. Theodore's health seems much better than it was last spring, and I think he is better than when he came home.
I rec a letter from Almeda a few days since saying that Mills wished to trade back on the farm, and asking my advice as to how she had better trade. It seems that she told him in the spring that he might come back if he wished to so that she feels under obligation to trade in some equitable way, also she wished to know what was best in relation to James whether to come to Minnesota or Ohio or stay in Brownville, also whether Mills could do better here than in Maine, when it is so

difficult for me to tell what to do myslef how can I tell what is best for others to do? In relation to Mills I tell her that in doing well here everything would depend upon his pluck and caliber, neither of which I had measured, in regard to James I think he had better stay under her influence a few more years if he should not get quite so much money, he is too young for western life, unless under the immediate influence of some good person, as to trading with Mills I advised her to accept his offer to pay back all she had put into or onto the farm. pay James $120. for his summer work pay her $330. for her right of dower, and give her a home there with one sixth of the produce of the farm and the taking care of her cow & sheep for four years, when they will have means sufficient to locate themselves in some more congenial clime, and where if they can not do more good they can enjoy more of the delights of social life, I wish that they were easily situated not far from you in Elyria. wouldn't you enjoy it. the more I see of this country the more I am inclined to think Ohio a pretty good place to live in, Should I ever have a home I think it quite as probable that it will be in Ohio as in any other place, but every thing is so changing so uncertain

here that it seems almost folly to make any calculation upon the future at least so far as to let our happiness depend upon the stability of human events. and yet we cannot separate them. they are so mixed that death alone can clean the tangled web, I suppose that it is not designed that we should be free from the influences which are about us on every side, and we should also remember that that we are not passive objects but active, in our turn exerting always an influence on all with whom we come in contact, and I suppose that it is wise not indolently to drift with the mass but to use all the normal strength we have to direct its course aright,
Affectionately yours,
S.W. Furber
S.W. Furber
