St. Paul Dec 8th 1857
Dear Mother
Your letter of Nov 18th I rec to day from Cottage Grove. I am very glad to hear from you as I felt somewhat anxious about Percie since I rec your last also at the Grove, I am very sorry that you have a bad cold and do hope that you will be relieved from t soon, I have done all that I shall do on my road untill the opening of Spring. The work I've done am'ts to about $1450, my expenses have been about $900, I was at work on the road about 5 weeks with 12 man and two teams. and one week since with three men putting in culverts. my Contract's about one half completed, Mr. Hamilton will share the profits after paying me about $4.00 per day for services. A short time ago I had almost concluded to hire a store here and sell grain & flour from Cottage Grove farmers. but somehow I do not feel very enthusiastic about it, Every thing is so dull here now that I fear I shall not make enough to pay expenses, and it may interfere with my work in the Spring, Government will expend some $20,000 in the Territory next season on roads which will be contracted for in February , I want to see if I can get a contract, It is very doubtful whether I shall go to Ohio this winter, the journey is so tedious from here to Prairie Du Chien, It is quite likely I may take a trip to see you in the Spring, Dear Percie how much I want to see him. What is it he'll "tell father when he comes" I should like to hear it now, do you  really think of going back to Maine in the Spring? and do you want to take Percie with you? I don't see how I can let him go any farther from me, and is it best for you to go away

so far? I'm not at all sure that it is, I do not wonder at your desire to get your children around you, and do not know why it would not be best for them and why you may not have your desire gratified with the exception of the one you have in Minnesota, and if I could do as well for myself in Ohio as here I would go there very quick, I am sadly perplexed at times to know what to do with myself and for Percie, I want him with me, I feel as though I could not be without him, and yet what can I do with him? I wish I could know just what my duty is in regard to him and myself. I can reconcile myself tom almost any lot or condition if duty requires it, 
Friday afternoon Dec 10th next day after Thanksgiving, I was interrupted in my writing and have not since had an opportunity of finishing untill now. I do my writing in Father's office and am subject to many intrusions, I do not like the idea of your going to Maine in the Spring I might conclude to go with you if you would like to have me, for two weeks we have had very mild weather, then barely snow enough to make good sleighing, I thank you for the scratches from "My little boy" & I think it valuable, I have just bo't me a $100 Melodian with which I expect to entertain myself very much these long winter evenings, My contract here for grading streets is completed, I get no money but get 30 percent interest and what is considered good security, I am very much obliged to you for your many good letters and hope you will not weary in writing them. I rec a letter with yours from the Du & Anna?, will answer soon much love to you all
S.W. Furber

St. Paul Jan'y 5th 1858
Dear Mother
Yours of Dec 25th I rec yesterday Many thanks for it, I do not think it probable that I shall go to Elyria this winter. notwithstanding I should be so glad to, whether I shall go in the Spring is also quite uncertain. because of this I shall go whenever I think it will do for me to leave long enough for such a journey and visit, you know I like to make long visits, Dear little Percie how much I want to see him. I should like to have heard him speak his piece, I fear that he is perhaps receiving too much notice, and I should judge it best for him not to attend school the remainder of this winter, however you can judge best about it, In regards ti clothes for him you will get what he needs, I will send some money to defray charges, I believe I left with you last Spring $10, will you let me know what has been expended for him, I'be been very much bothered while writing to day, will try to get an opportunity to write in a few days until then
Good bye
S.W. Furber

St. Paul Feb'y 3rd 1858
Dear Mother
I have been watching for a letter from you for a number of weeks. The last I rec from you was written Dec 25th which I answered at once. I do not know that I have anything of much interest to write about, I have been very quiet here This winter, I have hired a room until the first of April where I store grain for the Cottage Grove folks, but sell very little, there is no money here, I sometimes go to the Grove to see the folks there. we were all together New Years Eve, I shall start in a few days to examine a road to be built by the U.S. next May, June & July in direction of Lake Superior and extending too within seven miles of the Lake. a job of some $10,000, they have now advertised for proposals to be rec untill the 27 inst, but I deem it very uncertain about gathering the work, as there will. e much competition. Government's also going to build a road commencing at Fort Ripley and extending some forty miles in the direction of Pembina which will be let soon, there will not probably be much done in the City in grading of streets this coming season. There is more money to be made doing work for the City than for Uncle Sam if one can wait for pay, I am talking

of trading some land I bought last season for a farm near Cottage Grove. 18 miles from here. Should I buy the farm and find no other business I may turn farmer in May, the farm I speak of contains 200 acres, 100 of which is good timber, a very important item here, and has 25 acres under cultivation, buildings, a log house and various sheds, now should I turn farmer I should want Percie to help me, so you will not be surprised should you see me at Elyria after him in the Spring, and that is not improbable, and how much joy the thought of having him with me would give me, were it not for the pain I know it must give you to part with him, and O how glad would I be could you ever be with him and with me, and could I in any way see it to be my duty I would most gladly make my home near you in Ohio, Perhaps I may do so some time, but I cannot now see how, If I am not deceived I am not desirous of obtaining great riches, but I do feel a very strong desire to be free from embarrassment, and as fast as I can, without a sacrifice of health and happiness, I shall labor for that end, and if I am prospered a few years I hope to attain it. I have another change in view, of which I shall know more definitely in a few weeks, and of which

I shall consider it a duty and a pleasure to inform you, and may I not be assured that whatever will add to my happiness will receive your hearty approval? I know that it will, and I trust also that of all my friends, but more of this another time,
I have recently rec letters from Charles and Almeida, nothing of special interest from either, it seems that Mills has got over his desire to but back the farm. I am almost sorry for it without knowing why. Somehow it does not seem to me that Brownsville is the best place there is, does it to you? Still I do not know where Almeida could go at present to improve her situation, I rec a letter from Eliab and Mallie? Dec 4th to my answer to which and also to a letter written just previous I have rec no reply, I sometimes think it is a little singular, but I suppose they are very busy, it appears that Mr Harlow has got relieved from the presence of Mrs Nesbit, I wish him much joy, My room and fingers are both getting cold, Good night
Samuel
Thursday morning. I do not know of anything further too write only that I wish very much ti get a letter from you and to see Percie. does he even think of coming to Minnesota or talk much about me? it seems as though I could not wait till Spring to see him, with much Love to all
S.W.F.

Samuel
Bangor
July 30th, 1856
Dunbarton
Bangor July 30th 1856
Brother Isaac,
I feel as I must write you to night although I hardly know what to say. I fear that Lucy is failing fast and that we may at any moment recalled to part with her. She has lost strength for two or three days very much and her cough is growing worse distressing her very much to raise anything unclear lungs. There are small abscess's constantly forming and breaking on her lungs, Dr McRowen calls them cormica?. Our hope is that she may find relief from confinement within a few days. I do not know that I can ask you to come to Bangor but I do feel a very earnest desire that you come here. Her efforts sometimes in raising are such that we fear her strength will fail. I will try to write you daily
Yours
S.W. Furber

Samuel   Bangor
July 31 1856
Dunbarton
Bangor July 31st 1856
Brother Isaac
Last night Lucy had a hard cough almost the whole night. to day she is much easier and we feel more hopeful about her. her vomiting which has continued untill within a day or two has ceased and what food she has eaten yesterday and to day we hope has done her good. We have been disappointed so many times thinking that she was better that we hardly dare feel much encouraged to night but we will be thankful that she is more comfortable. Mr Rider and Almeida went home yesterday without any hope of his recovery and a probability that he may very suddenly be taken away by the cancer eating at the artery. I do not know that such a termination could be regretted.
Love to Nettie
S.W. Furber

Samuel Bangor Aug. 1st 1856 Dunbarton
Bangor Aug 1st 1856
Brother Isaac
Lucy slept about all of last night without once coughing waked at 5 in the morning very much distress for breath until half past six she suffered very much without any cough when she was relieved by the breaking of a small abscess on the lungs and has been quite comfortable since she has had then abscesses quite frequently for two or three weeks past and they are always mended just before breaking with a lightness and considerable distress, but the one this morning was much worse than any before Dr McRowen says we must expect them to continue until about the time of her confinement which he thinks may be in a few days. We hope she may then find relief but have many fears that she may sink under it.
The weather for a week past has been oppressively hot and there have been many cases of Cholera Morbus, but one fatal case I believe, a daughter of Dr Mills near us aged about 12 years
S.W. Furber

Samuel Bangor Aug. 3d 1856 Dunbarton
Bangor Aug 3d /56
Brother Isaac
Since I wrote you Friday afternoon Lucy has been quite comfortable or rather has not suffered as she has at other times, has had no abscess since the one friday morning. has had less fever, feet swoolen less appetite better and some little improvement in strength. Dr McR said to day that she looked better than for 4 weeks before. he felt encouraged that her system showed recuperation power, another day may dash all our hopes. yet we will be thankfull for this little reprieve? which she has from severe pain The rest of us are all well Love to Nettie
S.W. Furber
vertical writing follows
If Lucy continues comfortable I may not write you every day.

Samuel Bangor Aug. 6 1856 Dunbarton
Bangor Aug 6th 1856
Brother Isaac
We recd yours of the 2d inst last eve. were very glad to hear from you and that you were all well Since I wrote you Sunday up to 11 O'clock last night Lucy had been quite comfortable when her labor commenced and at three O'clock a daughter was born to us weighing 4 1/2? lb Lucy and the child are both better than we could have expected I think. there is a chance that the child may live. In regard to Lucy we hope that the disease upon her lungs may take a favorable turn we can tell nothing at present only that she is to day quite easy, Percie is the proudest person in the house at the accession to the family Yours S.W. Furber

Samuel Bangor Aug. 7 1856 Dunbarton
Bangor Aug 7th 1856
Brother Isaac
Since I wrote you yesterday afternoon Lucy has we fear failed she had a very restless night and was this morning very much distressed for breath got a little easier about 10. O'clock and since then has been rather drowsey and does not seem to be entirely conscious when awake, we have many fears that she will be with us but a few days at the longest, The little one seems pretty well and. could it have a Mothers care I think it might live Eliabs family have gone down river a few days for Maria's and the baby's health 
S.W. Furber

Bangor Aug 16th 1856
Brother Isaac
I hardly know what to say in regard to Lucy's health. We hope that there is some improvement. She coughs and raises less and has less fever but is troubled now with diarrhea we think that she is as strong now as one week since, or rather is not any weaker, She commenced to day taking Cod Liver Oil from which Dr McRowen hopes she will receive decided benefit. Dr Mc says that if the disease on the lungs is inflamatory, and he thinks it most likely that

it is, that she may get well but if it is tuberculus her chances are very small indeed, The little one does not seem so well to day as usual. I have many fears in regard to it, the effect of its death upon Lucy would be very much to be regretted
Eliab has gone to Searsport to spend the Sabbath with his family
I have written you very frequently for two or more weeks but have not heard one word from you. Do you receive my letters?
Yours
S.W. Furber

Samuel Bangor Me Oct. 18 1856 Dunbarton
Bangor Oct 18th 1856
Brother Isaac
We have not heard from you for some days and feel quite anxious to know how your are all getting along. I went to Milo last week with your Mother and Percie whom I left there. I came home by the way of Dover stoping overnight with Mrs Cochran which revived old memories, Eliabs folks have taken up their abode at my house. They keep house and board me and family, it seems very odd to take the position of a boarder. I believe I feel day by day more and more my loss, no loved one to greet me as I find my way home. I am now finishing two rooms one in each Attic which seemed to be necessary to accomodate us all when do you think to go to Elyria?

I wish that you had some of my housekeeping fixins when you set up in Elyria. Irving has cut 3 or 4 teeth since they came to my house and seems now quite well, needing very much a little wholesome neglect. Give much love to Nettie
Good night - S.W. Furber

Bangor Oct 19th 1856
Brother Isaac
We rec your letter last evening, and were very glad to know that you are all so well as to be able to start on your journey next week In relation to my sending you house keeping fixins, I hardly know what to say, There has yet been no positive trade made, but we have been talking, and I shall probably sell to Eliab in my interist in the store and my house and lot. Whether I sell to him or not I have pretty much made up my mind to leave Bangor, for a journey West My lumber operation will come out so that I shall not be able to pay P & R? all that due Fig Bradeen? owe

them and probably not my half of it. Am in hopes to make some compromise with them but cannot yet tell. I have secured Fa? Metcalf by the putting into your hands last spring my House, all that I and Fa? Bradcam owe them. As I have to begin the world again, so far as property is concerned, I do not feel like doing it here. A Mr Douglas minister at old Town is talking of buying some furniture and Carpets of me, was to be at my house with his wife yesterday but the storm prevented expect them tomorrow. I think they may buy a sofa and tables and chairs and perhaps Carpets You know pretty well what I have in the house (Eliab wants nothing) and whatever you wish me to I will pack and send

to Cleavland to whosever order you wish. freight from here to Cleavland is about $2.00 per 100 lbs I have some silver ware which I do not wish to sell, but would be very glad to let you have for the present. Say Cake Basket. 4 large spoons 1 1/2 Dry Tea opium salts & C. I suppose they would be no trouble in packing crockery so as to go safe. I will send just whatever you wish. A great deal of love to love to Nettie I am very much obliged to her for her letter, it does me a great deal of good to receive such kind assurances of sympathy
with much love S.W.F
I have one Hair matress for a single bed

Samuel Bangor Nov 8. 1856 Elyria
Bangor Nov 8th 1856
Brother Isaac
Enclosed I send you inventory of Merchandise to shipped to you by Steamer next Monday. I have marked it "Dr E DeWitt, Elyria Ohio" Thinking that perhaps it might get better dispatch in Cleveland he being known there as a Rail Road Man. I have made a bill separate from the inventory, it is a pretty difficult matter to get all the prices to suit myself, and whether they will suit you is still more improbable, I will send you bills of lading which will come from Boston. The Agt here says the freight will be $1.13 per 100 lbs from Boston to Cleveland and probably $1.18 to Elyria, All well How do feel Politically S.W. Furber

Samuel Bangor Nov 6. 1856 Elyria
Bangor Nov 6th 1856
Brother Isaac
I have been packing crockery & c for you to day have not time to night to give you a full list. I have packed - 2 wash bowls & Pitchers & Chambers. 2 Brittanica Li? pots & Coffee Pot. 1 Doz Tumblers 1 Doz Reserve plates 1 " dish 1/2 Doz egg Glasses. and about all the crockery I had in the house. 2 Doz knives & forks, Carver and fork &c&c. Tin Pans. Steams, plates dippers &c. Shovel, tongs, poker & stand, one carpet 14x15 for Parlor 1 do 12x15 for Camben quality poor being my sitting room carpet. Bed. Matress Pillows, 1 pr Blankets, will send a full inventory on list by Monday when I shall ship them   S.W.Furber

Bangor Nov 13th 1856
Brother Isaac
Yours of the 8th inst was rec this evening. I was very glad to learn of your safe arrival at Elyria. May much happiness attend you and yours wherever you may be. your Goods I shipped last Monday, put them in care of an Agt of the Western RR here, who said they would be in Elyria this week. You ask if I am decided to leave Bangor? Yes. Perhaps I do worry, but there are various reasons, which to me seem sufficient to advise such a course. In my lumbering operation of 53 & 54 I lost more than all I was worth and all that I have earned since and I feel that I can meet that demand sooner by leaving than by staying in Bangor. I have no cap-

ital in Tom's business and am of no benefit further than what my labor is worth, by selling out Eliab might obtain a partner with some capital which would make business much less embarrising and more profitable for him, And further I feel that I might be happier in some other place than here. every thing so reminds me of other days, and forces comparison with These present days, That I would turn away from these loved places, and seek to forget my sorrow in the excitement of new scenes and new pursuits, perhaps I take a wrong view of things and am taking an entirely wrong course. I do not feel so decided and clean concerning what course to take as I wish I did. and in the event of my leaving here I do not feel at all decided upon what course to take, as would be very natural in my thoughts are

much upon Minnesota, and I have thought that I should at any rate visit them in the spring, If I owed no man any thing I think, I would buy a little peice of land, and get my bread from the ground. I have had for a long time a strong desire for the quiet of such a life. perhaps if I should try it. that I should not find it what I hope
Mother and Percie came home day before yesterday, both quite well. PP especially so Much love to Nettie
Tell Brother DeWitt that I have recd the Picture, and Anna her letter
S.W. Furber

Samuel Bangor Dec 2 1856 Elyria
Bangor Dec 2d 1856
Brother Isaac
Eliab I believe wrote you yesterday in relation to your Mothers sickness. I think he has been considerably excited, I cannot this evening but feel some anxiety in regard to her. We tho't at noon that she was really better, but since then she has had more fever and pain. She coughs considerable but raises nothing and is very restless. I feel that she will improve in a day or two, will keep you daily advised, The rest of us are all quite well, Our river is closed with ice much love to Nettie S.W.F.

Bangor Dec 19th 1856
Brother Isaac
Your letter in relation to your books was rec this morning. Sometime when it is not so cold as now (20 below and very windy) I will look them up and carry them if to be found when I go west which I think will be in April. I shall also take Percie with and your Mother if she will go. I have yet said nothing to her in relation to going. nor have I heard her express any opinion about going. I think that I shall urge her to go to Elyria in the spring but I suppose she feels that her home is in Milo, she is now quite well and gaining strength slowly, I wish clean? Dr McRowen

from the charge of inefficiency made by Brother De Witt
She was taken sick Sunday or Saturday night. Eliab employed Dr Payne unitll Wednesday afternoon, when he yielded to other persuasions and Dr McRowen was called to attend upon her and I can but feel that he saved her life
My business here will probably be so far closed that I can leave here in April. Think I shall go to St Paul and then determine what next to do, Father has written about building a Steam Saw Mill there. it seems that it might do well. Logs are worth $8.00 per 1000 ft and Board $20.
I think that a few hundred dollars invested in the right

place somewhere in the west might afford a great income. the question is to find that place. May it not be at Superior on the west point of Lake Superior! I can probably settle with Pendleton & Ron? by giving four notes for $ 1000, each payable in 2, 3, 4 & 5 years, perhaps add the fifth. They are perfectly willing that I should go west. in that case I should have perhaps $1000 to carry with me and the Penn Land with say $340. to pay on it next August and I should hope with health to be able to meet such notes and finally to get free from debt. The longer our last winter three years ago lumbering

Samuel Bangor Dec 19, 1856 Elyria
operation will not be less than $22000, twenty two thousand If I pay P & R $4000 and F? Metcalf $4000, it will leave $14000 for P & Ron and Bradeen who may pay $3000. Ron has told me that if I want to go west that I may give them my notes for just what I have a mind to, and pay them if I can. It makes a pretty hard show but then have been much worse ones and P&Ron feel perfectly pleasant in regard to it. I expect great things from the Penn Land in time. I offered to give it to P&Ron but they say keep it. What do you think of it all? S.W. Furber

Bangor Jan'y 16th 1857
Brother Isaac
Yours of the 8th inst was recd yesterday. Certainly $1500 is good pay But would you like to live at Du Quoin? I supposed that Netties health would be an objection. I do not know what to advise you, if you were on some Roads for instance the Minnesota and North Western that you would get more pay and have opportunities for buying land which you could not otherwise have. but perhaps you might make a fortune somewhere else while waiting for that Road to be begun. I suppose that you could have done far better with your money for yourself than to have let it to Furber & Metcalf, but I know of no remidy for that I am sorry and hope some time to be able to remunerate you in part for your loss.

I have been to Milo and Brownville this week Mr Rider is failing, he cannot live many weeks perhaps not many days. he suffers terribly. but has as yet been able to eat enough so as not to suffer from hunger. Almedia is now quite well and cheerfull as possible under the circumstances. There has been quite a revival among the young people in Brownville. some 20 have made a profession. Lizzie is very much interested and hopes she has found the pearl of great unclear They are all well at Charles' I believe that Albina and Maria both contemplate and extention of their households sometime, Eliab I suppose has written you what other news there might be if any, I start next Monday for Boston shall spend two or three weeks in mass and N.H.

with my friends then. I have got to be at home by the 10th day of Feb'y to serve as a Juror in the Criminal Term of the Supreme Court. I rec a letter from Father a few days since, he wishes me to go to Minnesota early in the Spring to do his business for him while he comes East. I shall probably leave here the last of March. I had determined to carry Percie with me. but your mother wishes very much for me to leave him. I tell her that I should be more tempted to leave him with her at Elyria than here on a Milo. Cant tell what I shall do yet Yours S.W. Furber

S.W. Furber St Paul May 16, 1857 Elyria
St Paul May 16th 1857
Brother Isaac
I arrived here May 1st at 6.30 A.M. next day went to Cottage Grove and came back here yesterday. I found the folks here all well, with the exception of Theodore about whom I feel quite anxious I like Minnesota The Legislature has now been in session three weeks, trying to dispose of the Lands granted to this Term? for building Rail Roads A bill passed the House yesterday for engrossment incorporating the Minnesota and Pacific Railroad Co" The Co unclear& C "from Stillwater via St Paul and Anthony to Sioux Wood River, with a branch from St Anthony via Anoka, St Cloud, Crow Wing to St Vincent in the Red River of the North Near the mouth

of Pembina River" This Bill will undoubtedly become a law. The Corporators about fifty in number are Directors for one year. Father is one. Saint Staunchfield one, and numerous others over whome father thinks he can have considerable incluence. The first meeting of the directors will be holden Tuesday June 9th at St Paul
The Road will be surveyed at the earliest possible day, to stop preemptions, as the act of Congress does not effect the right of premptors untill the road is surveyed and marked, Now do you want to be Chief Eng of this Road? I hope that if so, with proper effort you may get that position Please to send an application with such and all recommen--

--dations as will be of value. and we will see what can be done. Will write you again as soon as the bill finally passes, or fails to pass. Father will not start for the East untill after the middle of June.
Olive and Mr Haskell intend going East in the fall. so that if you should come out here that I hope to have a chance for your Mother to come to Elyria
Please to write so soon as you receive this. 
Love to all S.W. Furber
It may be advisable for you to come here before the meeting of the directors if am Eng'r were here ready to commence a survey, it might be of importance in the view of the directors. if it is that best will advise you

Saint Paul May 18 /57
Brother Isaac
The Rail Road bills are all passed, and the Minnesota and Pacific Co are organized. Edmund Price President, Father talked with him about you, Price says that they will do nothing this year but make preliminary survey, says that he will give you charge of a section next Spring, I do not think that they have engaged any one as Chief Eng'r of this road, Mr Price took your address and I tho't seemed pleased to do so. remarking that the ILL Central would employ none but good men, he is acquainted I think he said with Col

Mason, at least with his reputation, I rec a letter today from Obed Foss. who wishes for employment with you, he is a good mathamatician, graduate of West Point and a good kind of a man, he may write you, he is in Bangor, I have not done much here yet, been looking about some, do not know but I shall go out with an exploring party for the P. Road, Mr Price tho't to day that he might like to have me.
This is a beautiful country, very, and I like. but its people and their customs not so much. Money! Money!! Money!!! Three percent. How it shuts out every thing that is better.
Father will go East about the

first of July, Theodore is here now, his health is very poor, he intends starting East with his wife one week from next Monday to go to a Water Cure Establishment, Where, he has not decided, you may see them in Elyria. I have many fears in regard to his getting well,
Tell Anna that I will write her one of these days,
Love to Nettie
Yours S.W. Furber

S.W.F. July 13 57
Saint Paul July 13th 1857
Brother Isaac
There is one subject which sometimes gives me uneasiness. what would become of Percie should I in any event be suddenly taken away. would you be willing should he thus be left to take him and love him? And would Nettie make room for him? trusting in Providence for your reward,
This thought in relation to him is not a new one, I have pondered the matter often, neither is there any

reason why I now particularly refer to it. Life is always so uncertain that we should never leave any duty, most especially one that we owe to another undone I trust that I may be spared to watch over him and protect him, but if not others must do it with hope of but little reward and to no others would I more hopefully commit him than to yourself and your dear Nettie. Should you feel willing to consent to it, I will be relieved from much anxiety about him in the event of his being left alone
Yours S.W. Furber

S.W. Furber St Paul Aug 15, 1857 Elyria
St Paul Aug 15th 1857
Brother Isaac
I want you to tell about all you know in relation to the grading of Rail Roads. the Minnesota, Pacific Road is to be put under contract between here and St Anthony this fall. the work to be done next winter, and I want to be prepared to make a bid. I think that work here generally is being done at very high prices, and there may be an opportunity to get a good contract. Please to post me up, I don't believe there is much probability of your obtaining such a position on this road as you would wish. The President and Directors have too many pets. The subscriptions to this road are

less than $400000. The first portion of the road to be finished will be from here to St Anthony, I do not know of any thing of particular interest at present. I've written to your Mother quite often so that you get all the news from her. How is Nettie and the boy? Give her much Love and best wishes. Our double headed convention is still in session and it is probable that they will give us two constitutions. Hon Stephen A. Douglas arrived in town yesterday. The Dimocrats are making quite a fuss over him. What do you think of the Missouri Election?
Yours S.W. Furber

St Paul Sept 12, 1857. Saml. Furber Elyria
drawing of St Paul SAINT PAUL in 1857 Engraved by J.W. Orr N.Y.
St Paul Sept 12th 1857
Brother Isaac
Yours of Aug 27 was duly rec. I am much obliged. I saw one of the executive Committee yesterday who told me that they would not probably commence work this season on acc of the pressure in the money market. the name of the Chief in the M&P. R.R is Shepard. I am not acquainted with him and do not know where he is from, "Uncle Sam" is to expend a few thousand dollars on the road from Point Douglas to Stillwater by way of Haskell, This fall grubbing and leveling making culverts &c I intend to make an offer. I am looking daily now for Father after his arrival I shall be more at liberty and intend to look

about more than I have yet done. Business here seems to be quite brisk although business men are saying that the "times are hard" were it not for the Jublie improvements going on here I think that it would be very dull. The Republican State Convention met in this City this week and have made nominations for State Officers. Election Oct 13th they feel pretty confidant that they will carry the State but I judge it to be very doubtful, although the nominations are generally satisfactory. There is a feeling that in the Constitutional Convention they sacrificed right to policy. how far this feeling may affect the vote in Oct I cannot judge. it will certainly rob the party of the enthusiasm of many of its best men, there are many men here who believe that a colored man is as capable of voting understandingly as a raw Irishman as an Indian, I profess to believe that myself.
Crops here are generally good. The grasshopers destroyed the most of the crops above St Anthony within three miles of the river. Corn is backward and perhaps not so good as usual, but if the frost holds off a short time longer there will be very good crops. There will be but little produce required to be bro't from below this fall. although I suppose there is not near the amount

in the Territory that will be needed before another harvest.
How does the money panic affect the Elyria people? Is it not a little singular that the great crash which has been hovering over the West with such awful visage, like a kind of ill omen should alight in Wall Street? "Pluck the beam &c" Steamboats have been making their trips on the river very regularly all the season, occasionally getting stuck on Beef Slough unclear. What do you hear from Eliab this fall? I have not rec a letter from Maine since I left there, I have written to Eliab three.
How is Nettie and the boy? Much love to all, Yours S.W. Furber

S.W.F. St Paul Feb. 25, 1858
St Paul Feb'y 25th 1858
Isaac & Nettie
Your's of the 17th I rec last evening, was very glad to hear from you, that you are all so well and happy. From past experience I can sympathize with Isaac in being bothered for money. This winter I have no money and want none, so it does not perplex me very much. There is but very little money in our Territory, Our State (?), County and City are each issuing scrip for their indebtedness, State scrip bears 12 percent, County 10. percent interest, City more. This serves for a home currency as from 75 to 90 cents on the dollar, and will pay taxes at par. The Loan Bill has not yet passed, but will when we have nay Executive department for our state, we have no governor and it is questionable whether our State legislature can make any valid laws, our wise builders of a Constitution make provision for a session of the legislature in Jan'y, but our governor elect cannot be qualified untill after we are admitted into the Union, it is now proposed to submit the constitution to the people in a few weeks for amendment, providing for the

inaugeration of the governor at an early day, after which the machine will be would up and set in motion. Uncle Sam, nucleus volens, Every man in Minnesota prefers staying out of the Union to being admitted if Kansas with the Lecompton villainy (Mrs Cunningham's Child, as Kansasites call it) is to be draged into the Union hitched to our skirts, The good "Dimecrats" here are muttering curses long and deep upon the head of "Jimmy? Platform", Then it is quite probable that they will, within on year, be cringing and fawning to the Administration like a whiped puppy. I rec a letter a few days since from Mr & Mrs Crosby of Hampden, Mr Crosby's health is quite good now, he had the hypo very bad last summer, they seem to be in very good spirits. Rufus & William are in Kansas, doing as they suppose quite well for themselves. I've heard nothing form Eliab for a long time, how is he getting along? 
Friday afternoon. I was interrupted yesterday, and I've been engaged to day with Mr Hamilton in making our bid on the Superion Road. There were some ten or twelve bids. we shall not know before this evening or tomorrow morning who gets it, I do not much expect nor desire the contract, going into the woods in June July and Aug to fight mosquitoes will not be a very enviable business. I think that if we

do get it at the prices we have bid that we can make a very good job of it,
If I were not tied up here with the grain and flour which I am trying to sell I would go down to Elyria and stop untill the river opens, but I do not see how I can, I want so much to see Percie, I am afraid he will almost forget me, If we do not get this Superior road to build I think that I must go to Ohio either when the river opens or as soon as we complete our last fall contract, probably about the first of May, I was going to write Mother, but I know nothing further of interest now to communicate, perhaps I will write her soon, I feel that I don't want her to go to Maine. While I suppose she feels that she ought to go, If there is any probability of Charles coming to Ohio in the fall had she not better wait and go back with him if she must needs go? Wont Charles yet come to Ohio to live? I almost think he will. I wish I could myself, what are farms worth in your County?
Monday morning March 1st, We do not get the Superior Road. it was let for prices at which I think the contractor (an Irishman) will lose money, It now seems quite certain

a Loan Bill of some kind to the amount of five million will pass, if so, I think there will be a good deal of business here next season. Would you like to come here to take charge of a section of road? Write as often as you can I am always glad to receive letters from you With much Love S.W. Furber

S.W.F. St Paul June 15 1858
St Paul June 15th 1858
Brother Isaac
We arrived here Friday at 4 Oclock A.M. per Steamer Milwaukee, all well although somewhat jaded, we were detained twenty four hours between Madison and Prairie Du Chiene. Some three miles of the road was under water and in some places badly washed, we stoped over night, at a one horse tavern, at a place called Mazomania, what an euphonious name. The Upper Mississippi never appeared in gayer habiliments, beautiful beyond all comparison, the first Bbl of apple came to hand to day. Charges 2.98$ freight on the balance will be less. The Boats on the Miss charge 30 cts per 100lbs but no package less than $1,00. I can probably sell them here for about 8 cts, no very great speculation. Money matters here are in a shocking condition, we have not yet commenced housekeeping will not until after our return from Cottage Grove next week, Mother F's health is

better than it was, although not now very good, Day after tomorrow there is to be organized here a Congregational Church with about 20 members, this ought to have been done years ago
I have learned from the Bangor papers more particulars about the fire it seems that the fire originated in another building and that S? & M's building was nearly destroyed. That their loss was from 10,000 $ 12000, and was covered by insurance. it may be that they will not suffer by this fire. I hope it may be so, I got a bill of my tea yesterday. so that they saved that, The spring here has been dry, farmers are suffering now for want of rain, what think of that, Eliza is well pleased (so far) with Minnesota and especially St Paul, Much Love to all S.W. Furber

S.W.F. Bangor May. 24 1858
Bangor May 24th 1858
Isaac
Yours (date forgotten) I saw Saturday on my return from Milo, You may buy me a Bbl of apple and send to St Paul via Mill & Mill R.R. perhaps it would be cheaper to send it via Cleveland, that is the way that Bullock sends freight to Chicago, we are expecting now to leave here one week from to day , and be at your place the last of the week, we are all well and hope to be Almeda has not sold to Mills. she may next fall, but not entirely certain, she wishes to know where she had better go if she trades with Mills, can she buy any thing of a farm about Elyria for a thousand dollars?
Yours S.W. Furber

S.W.F. Aug 5 '58
St Paul Aug 5th 1858
Brother Isaac
How warm and how wet it is. grain here very badly rusted, half crop, corn of a gigantic growth and if the season is long enough the crop will be very large, since the last days of June, when every thing had become much parched, there has been a constant succession of heavy showers, and such thunder and lightning I never heard of or saw, last night there was a model shower for half an hour. I think that the whole heavens were in a perfect blaze from half to two thirds of the time, and one continuous roar of thunder and such thunder, none of the mutterings which we hear in the East, but a continual Crash as if a thousand worlds were were being broke to

pieces about ones head. Isn't there joy in such a storm? I think so.
How do you and Nettie and the babies and Jennie and the Doctor and Anna and Hattie and Libby and all the folks do? Here we are all well. Mother F's health is rather uncertain, but the rest of us are quite confident that we are in excellent health, Percie seems quite well and enjoys himself much. I wish he had a larger run, he is not disposed to form an extensive acquaintance I believe there is but one child that he plays with at all, I do not encourage him to play with many children, but wish that he would get acquainted more easily than he does. 
I have done nothing since I came back and do not see that I am likely

to work here is being done for prices at which contractors must lose money. If things do not look better I may go to farming next spring. Some of the R.Roads are being built, but every thing is done by skulldugery, not much chance for any body unless they are willing to lend themselves to all kind of fraud and iniquity. 
What can dried apple and cheese be bought for in Elyria next Sept or October? also butter? will you make some enquiry and let me know, I have sold the apple I bo't cleared $2.00 per Bbl. Have sold but little of the tea, large quantities in this market, could have done well in cheese if it would have come without damage. freight on apples was one cent per pound on soap five, I have never heard one word of the fire in Bangor but what I saw in the

papers, what do you know of Eliab's loss? With much love to all yours & C
S.W. Furber
Percie says I may send Uncle Issac and Aunt an armful of love

St Cloud Jan'y 31st 1859
Brother Isaac
I rec a letter from you some two months which I should have answered long since, It has been about two months since I bo't a farm and moved to Cottage Grove. The Farm I bo't had 30 acres broke last June 340 rods of post board fence, no other improvement, price $1625, 35 acres of timber, balance prairie, it lays on the West of Theodore's farm, 120 acres. I am boarding this winter with Theodore since I moved to the Grove. I have engaged to come back to St Paul in the Spring. have made an engagement there to go into a steam saw mill, where I think the prospect for business is quite good. The Mill I am going into has 2 mule saws, 1 sliding saw, 1 lathe machine, 1 shingle machine, 1 of wood  and planing mills, and a splitting machine for making siding, we can manufacture from 3 to 4 million feet of long lumber per season of eight months, besides shingles, lathes and planing, Four of us form a company for operating the Mill, I have the general care of the Mill, the others are, the engineer, the bookkeeper and salesman at the yard, and one of the Mill owner who has care of the general business

Each have 1/9 and the Mill 5/9 of the profits. The Mill cost about $2000, the Mill owners have to make their own insurance and pay taxes, The Mill owners have a contract for from 3 to 4 million of logs, now being cut, to be delivered in the St Paul Boom, for $4,25 per ?, they will cost in The Mill Boom about $5, which we have at cost, lumber is selling for from $10 to $20 per the planed siding and flooring for $25, but the great draw back will be to sell all we can make, and then we have to trade a great deal of it, I think we can saw boards for $200 and can hire men and pay them 2/3 of their wages in lumber, I cannot see why we may not make a good business of it, I wish now that I had not bought the farm at the Grove, but I hope to sell it soon, I am now on my way into the woods where the logs for our Mill are being cut, I have been up once before this winter about 4 weeks since, I shall stop in the woods this time two or three weeks. It is about 125 miles from St Paul a few miles west from Fort Riley, There is a man now engaged in drawing the machinery and light portion of a steamboat from the Mouth of the Crow Wing River to the Red River of the North where he will build a new Hull for it. The portage is about 120 miles from here (St Cloud) to Breckenridge which is the head if navigable water on

The Red River is 140 Miles. There is now being cut through a road from this place to Breckenridge, about 7 miles below Breckenridge the Gen'l Government are building a Fort Called "Fort Abercrombie" from St Anthony to this place Steamers run most of the season (from 2 to 3 months) The Red River is said to be navigable for steamers from Breckenridge to Lake Winnipeg from the West or South West , is said to be navigable for the steamers for 700 miles, to a point where it is but 150 miles portage into the head of Frasier's River. There is a vast country to the North West of here which must be opened up within a few years and I cannot believe that business will remain at its present low condition for a very long time, I believe that the putting of this steamer on the Red River will secure the entire trade of the Hudson By a Co through St Paul. Goods have been landed within six months at St Paul from Liverpool via New Orleans for $1,00 per 100 lbs,
Our Cong'l Church at St. Paul is getting along quite as well as we could expect, all are not coming into it who should do so, The Presbyterians are making every possible effort to induce Congregationalists coming into the place to unite with them. They may sometimes succeed, but I believe this society is

destined to be a strong one. but it will for some years have many a hard struggle to keep above water, it has doubled its membership since its organization which was not much to do as it at first had but 15 members, Our Minister, Rev'd Burdett Hart, is just the man for the place, an ardent Christian, an eloquent preacher, prepossessing in his appearance and winning in his manners, one whom his people will love, and all respect, We organized a Cong'l Church at the Grove about 5 weeks ago with 13 members, four by profession among them Alfred Homes and my brother John. Since then we have had quite a revival there. There have been some 20 Engineers, when I left there the 25th inst there had been 3 family alters erected, my brother Theodore is among those who have begun the new life,
We are all in excellent health. Percie is growing tall and stout I think the climate is good for him. I've not sent him to school since I have been here. I think he learns quite as much at home. he is a very good reader and is learning to spell quite well, I rec a letter from Mother a few days since, all well in Bangor. How sad that Sam'l Harlow? should be in the condition he is, following his brother Charles
Give a great deal of love to Nettie and the children, also to Anna and the Doctor
Yours
S,W, Furber

Cottage Grove March 24th 1861
Brother Isaac
I am going to write at this time about that box of roots and shrubbery, you said in your letter that you could send a box of any size that I was willing to pay express charges on if you knew what I wanted or what would live in this cold region, I suppose that a box of the size of an 8x10 glass box would not cost more than $1.00 by express and would contain as many roots and slips as you would have to spare, I now have nothing in the way of roots or shrubbery, all kinds of currants, gooseberries, raspberries and blackberries grow well here, the common red currants can be got here as also the various kinds of strawberries, roses of all kind can be grown here, all have to be protected in the winter a few roots would be very acceptable. Honeysuccle and almost any kind of shrubbery will do well here, have you any lily of the valley I do not think there is any in Minnesota, you can put in such things as you think would be likely to grow here, it may be that the Express Co would not take a box of that kind without prepayment if so you pay the freight and forward the bill to me, have the box directed to me care of P.P. Furber St. Paul, We are well and hearty

have had a very pleasant winter with but little snow. The last week has been very cold Mercury to ten, it will however now take but a few days of pleasant weather to put our harrows (drags) in motion, There will be a great amount of land out into wheat here this year, I have just completed the agricultural statistics of this town for the State Statistical Bureau it shows in this town for the year 1860
No of farms in cultivation 55
No of acres  "                  3356
acres to wheat 1738, bushels 48,925, average for acre  28.1
"        "   corn 596,       "          24,560.           "               41.2
"        "   oats 748,       "           45,174.          "               60.4
The balance under cultivation to various other crops this we think is about as well as Ohio can do, but I would like some of your fruit,
I have to put in this year about 40 acres. shall put the most of it wheat, shall raise no more corn or oats than I shall want for consumption on the farm
April 5th I have very negligently delayed this letter and will now post it away, we are now having a fine rain, the first of any amount since October, the frost is now out of the ground sufficiently to flow, some wheat is sown and most of wheat will be put in next week if the weather should

be good, I shall sow about 36 acres of wheat and 10 of other crops, I have 40 acres open on my and I have six acres for which I have $12, wheat is worth in St Paul now 60 cts , corn 30, oats 18,
Much love to all
Yours
Letter ripped]

S,W,F,
Dec 11 1862
Cottage Grove Dec 11th 1862
Dear Mother
Perhaps you would like to hear from us if we have nothing in particular to say of ourselves more than that we are all well, I suppose that ere this year have rec a visit from Mehitable, wish that I could have gone along too, but then I suppose that it is some comfort to you to see her. I know it will be so to her to see you, We miss Bell and Rob't very much and almost hope that they may not like Ohio well enough to stop there, I wrote to Almeida some months since but have not yet rec any reply neither have I rec any answer from a letter to Charles, from Eliab I have

heard nothing for a long time, does he write to anyone?
I have been interested in reading in the Patent Office Report from 1861 an account of Grape culture on an island in the Western part of Lake Erie in 41º43', it appears that grapes do finely there, can good vineyards be made in Elyria? Our crops have been quite good this season and most of our farmers are getting ahead a little, I am feeling a little bad over the frowning of my horses this week, I had hired them to a lumberman to work in the logging woods this winter, he drowned them in Lake St Croix last Monday, he will have to bear the loss, but I do not expect to get another team that I shall like as well or that Percie can so safely handle, he had become very much attached

to them and was very much grieved at their loss, our winter school has just begun and he and Mary are attending 
I have been untill now very busy since early in the Spring, I out in 75 acres this year and had no help but a few dogs untill harvest, and have done a good deal of business beside, in June I made the assessment of this town which took me some two weeks, I was then on a board of Commissioners to appraise the school lands in this county which occupied me some thirty days, I had to enroll the Militia of this town four days in harvest, In Sept I rec the appointment of Assistant Assessor (under the U.S. Excise law) for this Co which has already furnished me employment for 36 days, and on the 6th of July I have to go to St Paul as member of the

House of Representatives, so that you will see that with my own and other peoples business my time is pretty well occupied, I have a young man working with me who is from Norwalk, Conn, and who will stay through the winter
I think that I have been very fortunate getting him, a fine steady boy of 20, The people of the state are still much excited about our red brethren the Sioux, There are some 200 of them in bracelets at St Peter whom we wish to have the satisfaction of hanging, and which our common father Abraham does not seem willing we should do, but we think that they will not be allowed to go unhung by the interference of any power, Nary they must or burn
Affectionately
S.W. Furber

St Paul Aug 8th 1863
Bro Isaac
Enclosed I send a five dollar bill on the Bank of Geauga in Painsville Ohio, it is called counterfeit here, perhaps Dr DeWitt will know whether it is or not, if it is bad you need not return it, if good send me back something for it,
I have been here two weeks doing "Deputy Provost Marshall" duty, the Irish did not want to be enrolled and instructed their "Biddies" not to give their names. The Enrolling officer had been driven from "the patch" and threatened with violence, A party of Depts were detailed to protect him and arrest offenders. The morning that they commenced enrolling in the Irish district we had to arrest four and put them in jail. When they "came down" and concluded to give names,
I am going home to night I expect Percie's up for me, we have had an exceedingly dry season and crops are quite green
We are all quite well,
With much Love
S,W, Furber

S.W. Furber
Dec 29 1864
Cottage Grove Dec 29th 1864
Dear Friends,
I have often thought of writing to you within this past year but lack of matter of any interest to communicate had deterred me. In that respect, I am no better off now but write for friendship's sake and in hope of hearing of your welfare or in return
I learned from Samuel that you had purchased the Bluffs farm  for Mr Chas Rich Bell wishes to know if he is still living there. I think it is a nice little place, near enough to the village (do you call Elyria a village?) to have the benefit of good schools, meetings society even. I would like know how you succeeded in your peach orchard experiment at Du Quoin, Did you trees suffer being frozen the unusual cold of last winter? I should like to know something about 
Perpendicular writing on left side of page Please excuse this horrid scribbling Remember me with much love to your mother and all of the rest --- Regards with love Bell

tho climate an country around DuQuoin and could I leave house next summer might be disposed to visit that part of Illinois and other parts of the West having a milder climate than Minnesota. My brother William made a hasty visit to Davenport and Iowa City last Fall, He speaks well of the country and of the terrain on which improved farms can be bought their. 20 to 30  miles west from Davenport wild lands are held at from $8.00 to $10.00 per acre; improved with good buildings from 20 to 25 dollars per acre
Samuel has been so fortunate as to have the affairs of M.S. Assessor? and Provost? Marshall for the past two years, which pays much better than farming. So for the present he is satisfied with Minnesota. We have had two very dry seasons and the past seasons especially the crops have been very light.
We have been gladdened by good news from our armies of late. It would seem as though the strength of the rebellion in the far south was about used up. I hope that now at least we can

see the beginning of the end. The new call for 300,000 more more men is going to leave this country very short of help. Some farms lay idle last year, more will undoubtedly the next. This may be partly owing to dry seasons and low water in the river. Our winter so far has been quite cold though generally pleasant very little snow, no sleighing,
We would be much pleased to see you all again. Could you not make us a visit next summer, Dr and his family accompanying yours. I think you would al enjoy a trip on the Mississippi (if the water is high enough) Minnie is at school, she also remembers with pleasure her visit to Elyria and frequently speaks about the boys. Please to remember us to Wilder  Charles and dear little May. One of our little ones is still sadly missed, but we hope and trust that with her it is well,
Please present our kind regards to Dr and Mrs DeWitt and assure them of the pleasure a visit from them would give us. Samuel's farming on

well. He is away from home a good deal on account of his Provost Marshall duties and his business as N?.S. Assessor, Our family is well except myself who have been laid up for two weeks with a lame back and am still unable to do anything. Hoping this will find you all in good health. I am dear unclear with much respect.
Yours Truly.

Rob't Watson

Dear Mrs. Metcalf, I ought long ago to have acknowledged letters of sympathy from yourself and mother, but have had little leisure this season in consequence of having no help in the house that I find it hard to get time to write many letters, but we often think and speak of you remembering how happy the children were at your house, The winter here thus far has been very cold. I think we never had so much very cold weather so early in the winter. Minnie walks more than a mile to school, She has gone frequently when the mercury ranged from twenty to twenty-five below zero. Little Isabel seems quite well most of the time though she has occasional spells of violent beating of the heart which gives us some uneasiness. We don't know whether Olive's disease commenced in that way but think there must have been something wrong about her a long time before we were aware of it.

Samuel W.F.
Jan 13, 1866
Cottage Grove Jan'y 13 '66
I.S. Metcalf
Dear Brother
I rec your letter of the 2d with its sad intelligence to day, words would fail me in any attempt to express my sorrow, I know that for our loved Mother we need not mourn, all's well with her and what a blessed meeting for Lucy when she welcomed her to those "Mansions" where the good and the pure only are, How cord after cord is being blessed which holds us here, and when the last one's severed may we be as ready and as well prepared as our dear mother was, then death can do us no harm. I very much regret that I could not see mother again there were so many

things I wanted to tell her, now I will have to keep them a little longer I would that I would pay a fitting tribute to our Dear Mother's Worth but I can find no words to express my admiration and love for her, to have known and been loved by her, as I trust I was, was no ordinary privilege, may her bright example and all of her Christian counsels be as seed sown upon good ground which shalt spring up and bear fruit unto eternal life,
We are now all quite well, our plans now are that Eliza and Percie start East early in May, make a short visit to Chicago and from there to Elyria and then Eliza goes East and waits for me to come home with her,  may start the first of July and may not until the first of Sept. I cannot be gone more

than two months on account of assessing, then I will have to let one monthly return go by, but these plans may all have to be changed or given up,
I am at a loss to know what to do with a mother for Percie, I want to give him better schooling privilages than we have here, and I do not want him entirely away from me for so many years as will be necessary to educate him, sometimes I think that the road will be made plain as I travel on, and again it appears to me that some fore thought may not be altogether improper, 
Give much love to Nettie and all the folks, kiss all the children for Uncle Sam,
Yours
S.W. Furber

Dear Brother and Sister Metcalf.
It is with much grief and sorrow that I also learn of the death of your beloved Mother: for although I can claim no relationship to her, yet I had seen and known enough of her, to love and esteem her very much
As I have had no mother to love on earth for many years, my heart had been drawn towards her, with strong affection
I had been looking forward with much pleasure to the time when I should see her again, praying that she might be spared a little longer: but the 'Lord' has ordered it otherwise ("He doth all things well") and while we mourn for ourselves let us all strive more earnestly to match the loved ones in that better world there to dwell forever with the Lord
With much love
Eliza K.? Furber

S.W. Furber
April 8, 1866
Cottage Grove April 8/66
Brother Isaac
I rec your letter written from Du Quoin, Our Spring is threatening to be a very late one, The roads are now nearly impassable, in many places entirely so , by reason of the snow, up to about the 28 of March, The weather continued very cold. The mercury below zero nearly every morning and but about four days in the month getting above 32º at noon, Since the first of April it has been warm enough to thaw the snow and make the roads bad exceedingly, There is but very little frost in the ground and it absorbs the the water a fast the snow melts and I think that we may have the ground settled nearly as early as usual
I think it quite probable that

Eliza and Percie may start East the first week in May. They will make a short visit in Chicago before going to Elyria.
What will be the best way for them in going from Chicago to Elyria? I believe there are no cars on the Northern Division of the C & Toledo RR, Had they better go to Cleveland or leave the cars at Oberlin or Grafton and get a team to take them to Elyria? Will you please to advise me in this matter,
What school books will Percie need? he has McNally's Geography, Robinson practical progressive arithmetic and Sanders 5th Reader & Speller, do you use any of them in your school?
I feel as much like rejoicing at the Conn Election and the passage of the Civil Rights bill over the veto as at Lee's surrender. it seems to me that the Conn Election is very

significant, if the Union Party could carry that state against all the influences that were brought against them why not carry every Loyal State at the fall elections? and if Congress will only heed the parable of the "Bulls" recently published in the Independent they may yet be a power in the settling of the difficulties which lie in the way of reconstruction
There is no doubt but it requires a higher order of talent to overcome the difficulties now in our way than to subdue Rebels in arms,
I think it most probable that I shall start East the first of July and be home the first of Sept, I cannot leave home more than eight weeks unless I should be released by Andy's axe
Yours
S,W, Furber

The Congregationalists are about to establish a College and Preparatory school in this state, The committee appointed at the General Conference last October to report at the next Conference upon the location of site, have invited proposals from any towns wishing for the location, such proposals to be handed in before the first of May, we are making an effort to secure its location here, we have raised here about $10,000, I am going this week to St Paul to solicit assistance there, they are making no effort to get the location, it will either be here or in the southern part of the state, I think we stand a very fair chance of obtaining it

You will see that affairs appears to be in better condition than last year. The flour all stands to my a/c. have sold 12 bbls 5.45. am going to send a few bbls to Milo. It is worth there 6.50. get it hauled for 50 cts. in March & April it will be worth 1.00 more than in Bangor. cost nothing for storage. The Brandywine is hauled up at Frankfort. last freight not settled. in the above schedule I changed it to my a/c at $10, which makes the earnings this year $63.36 cost 317.50. now stands without interest a/c $256.76. Mayo has paid nothing but has promised a post this week. expect we will have to wait till spring for post. Green & Smith have each given a note for $5.00. I think they may pay. I have not yet been to Corinna or Stetson. shall go soon unless I hear from them. I went into the Court House yesterday after consultation with Morrison decided to address another continuance on Fletcher's case. Godfrey says there is no defense. We must levey upon real estate within thirty days after judgment. so it is for our interest with Thurston to be out of the way with his suit before we get judgment

I closed a trade yesterday for 1/16 of the Schi?. H. Crosby $2.15 Went to Milo Jan 1st came home the 5 your mother came with me you pay us a visit she has written you to day and I suppose give you all the Milo news. Father has determined to sell his farm and go to Minnesota in the spring of 1851. Had a letter from Olive while I was at Milo. She has one of Mrs Judson's birds in her nest now some two months old. John boards with us this winter attends the Hampden Academy. Jan is here does not go to school. I have no business this winter but what I can create at home. Lucy is very busy this morning doing her baking so as to go to Bangor in the afternoon with me. she send a large peice of her love which you will please to find in this same envelope. Swarzy? in acknowledging the money I sent says our a/c with W&S is wrong in the insurance item they charge $4.00 you gave before? $1.45 you explained that to me once but I have forgotten about it. Have not ans their letter perhaps it is not necessary.
About your leaving Waterford. If they keep their house in operation stay. If they shut down? if you feel that their is any probability of receiving help from the water treatment go to Brattleboro if you can as easy as to come home unless you can have as good attention somewhere here as there you know best about that matter is there any water here suitable for you. I want you to continue the water cure system untill you feel satisfied or as long as you feel that there is any chance to receive help I do feel that I wish you to make a further trial of system. I am considerably at leisure this winter and you may consider me at your service if I can be of any assistance to you. either here or in other place
S,W, Furber
Hampden Jan 5th 1850

Thursday evening Oct. 31/51
am coming home Saturday will tell you all the news John will go up with me & perhaps Almeida come Monday we shall conclude about it when I get there we had better be all ready Lucy is very much more comfortable Ann arrived here quarter noon all well and happy. Eliab wrote to her in Boston & she started right along   we can't imagine why we did not have letters day before your birthday
Your mother has not seen fit to tell all. Our little one has gone. it did seem Tuesday that it might live, but God has taken it to himself. it does seem that it ought to have lived, but we know that our Father does all things right and we must try to feel that he does 
You will have all the particulars Saturday
S,W,F

Samuel W.F.  Hampden Oct, 31. 1850
J.M. Metcalf
Milo Me
red ink postal stamp--BANGOR Nov 1 Me.

Tuesday P,M,
I suppose that I must write a few lines to day. We were presented yesterday with a daughter whose life (like that of all) hangs by the merest thread but we feel today that we have reason to hope that that thread may grow to its usual strength Lucy is as well today as we could expect hope. what a night of anxiety, and we all ought to be thankful for so much mercy shown to us 
we cannot promise when we let your mother go. not this week certain. will write again by next mail
In haste
S,W,F,
Sam'l has left a space for me to fill but have I have not to say much they have a first rate old competent nurse from Bangor but we both have as much as we can do I talked with Suzy Menharid? going up Friday She said she couldn't spare me She should be crazy if I did She says Dear Joseph won't suffer you as I should They will do every thing for him
Where can Ann be?
A.M.M.
