Bangor, May 8th 1851
My Very Respected Sir
Trust of a late sate is in my pocket. I have seen your Uncle Nathaniel and have selected and distinctly labeled nine young and tender trees to be forwarded to your order at Milo by the very earliest opportunity, to wit
Bells Early         1 tree
Rib Stone Pipin  2 trees, winter good
Red Astrichan    1 tree, early rich
Baldwin              2 trees
Greening            1 tree
Flat winter           1"
Wine Apple         1"  Fall Lewarfish?

                          9

For which trees the Uncle aforementioned asks the sum of thirty-three and one third cents for each and every tree, the whole nine therefor amounting to the exact sum of three dollars. considering that the trees are low and the price high I shall charge no commission on this purchase
I take this opportunity to assure you of my distinguished consideration
S,W, Furber

Dear people all.
Samuel thinks best to send this by  tomorrow's mail, so I'll scribble a few words. Sissie Ive and Mrs. Webster called once. They are coming to spend this evening. Mrs. Aunt Natty, and a very estimable and fat old lady by the name of Page called this morning. I can't tell you how many people come to get a chance to emigrate with Mr. Furber. They will have quite a congregation. Samuel has bought a very pretty copy of Hannah More for Sissie -- gilt leaves for $1.50. Was that right? I am going to put a beautiful bookmark in it. She is a good girl. I have not rep'd Mrs. Thaxter's letter -- her tongue came instead yesterday. Her health is miserable. I hope the chair will come soon -- I do not love to be carried so much. Ann has sent $20 to Sissie to purchase a silk dress & Mantilla, so I shall send the skins together with "Beauties of Festus which I have bought for her. My cough is better. I daily drink doses of Comfry tea -- don't know but I feel as well as before I came. We are in momentary expectation of seeing our Frances arrive. Pa has not yet arrived and they cannot tell when they will start. I am very glad the curtains gave forth their treasures, and very sorry you worried about Sarte?"'Tis never worth while to worry, (Bardy?") I don't know whether syrup would be beneficial or not. perhaps fix some to send if there is suitable opportunities, & I will sugar it to suit myself -- it may be too bracing for me.
Seems to me I had a good deal more to say but cannot think now. Will write again and soon. Mehitable sends her love to Albina in particular and the rest of the folks in general. Mrs. Furber also sends love. Eliab has been there once. I wish and wish your stove was was like our good ones. Good bye

Hampden Nov 16, 1850
Dear Folks,
Lucy says she is "growing gradually better day by day, but her walking sticks, and ankle bones receive no strength" she walked across her room Thursday, but she is not strong enough it made her legs tremble some - she says "tell them I am going into the sitting room tomorrow" I think she wont go. she is gaining faster than I expected, and feels quite comfortable has no pain and is only weak, and tired of the bed and of doing nothing. We get along quite well and next week Ann and she will get on swimmingly. Ann is coming back Sat. and I return Monday dont fail for by that time my children will need me I guess Alfred was here yester, seem'd to think, should not go to Milo, but had not fully determined, expect Isaac next week. Mr Kimball came in boat with Alfred told him to tell Mr Wilson and the folks up there that he had returned to spend the winter in Bangor. Does that mean that he has heard that Mr W. is unable to stay, and he will come if wanted?
How does Mrs Sargent? have they moved yet
It is going to rain so Sam'l not go to meeting morrow is going up tonight so I send it for fear Lucy sends grat parcel love I want to write a word to children but hant time only be good, good

W.F. Albany NY
Albany Thursday noon
Folks at Elyria
We found ourselves at the Delavan House this morning at 10,15. have got along nicely left Cleveland at 3,50 P.M. Buffalo at 11.45 P.M. The Lake Shore Road was very good. We leave for Boston at 2.45 P.M. This day, and if we do not stop over night at Springfield or Worcester, which I shall do if Mother is tired shall get into Boston at 12 to night. the roads are in better order than I thought they could be, and are very free from dust,
Yours
S.W. Furber

Samuel Bangor Sept. 21 1856 Dunbarton
Bangor Sept 21st 1856
Dear Brother
Your letter of the 18" we rec last evening. we were very glad to hear from you, of your own continued good health, we have had many fears that you might be taken down with sickness. We should be very thankful that your health has been spared to you, that you have been enabled to watch over and care for all the dear ones about you. May it still be further spared and may all who are still sick be soon restored to health.
Dear Brother I do most sincerely sympathize with you in your great afflictions, in our dear Lucy's death I know that your sorrow is but little less than my own, and O! how every day these losses grow upon us, feeling more and more the worth and the love of those who have been taken from

us. Let us draw near to God and learn of him if we may why he is thus dealing with us, ad what he would teach us in this discipline of his. To the dear ones he has taken from us we know we feel that he has dealt in mercy, may we be enabled to feel that in their removal that he has been also in mercy dealing with us
Your Mothers health is I believe pretty good She was much worn down with the care of the dear little babe but is now recruiting her health and strength I am intending to go to Milo, perhaps the last of this week, and leave her and Percie then a few weeks. Percie's health is now quite good although his bowels are not in an entirely healthy condition. For the future we have made no definite arrangements Eliabs folks would I suppose move up here then being no valid objection, but it is very evident that Hatty and Maria do not wish to come, and neither your mother

now myself feel like urging them to come. Mr Obed Goes? formerly of Milo, whose wife is now at St Albans and is represented as being a good housekeeper, wishes to have her come and keep house for us and to take him for a boarder (he is a clerk for J.A. White) we did think that this might be a good arrangement, but your mother now thinks that she and Lizzy could keep house this winter by having the washing done. This would be the most pleasant for us all, but I am almost fearful to try it lest your mother be over taxed and wearied. I know not hardly what to do. Eliab thinks I had better sell my place and board with him but I do not quite feel as though I ought to or could. If it could be as well for you (which I suppose it cannot be) how glad we would be to have Nettie and Wilder come and live with us this winter and as much longer as it would be best for your

Dear Nettie, What can I say to you to comfort you? I will pray God that your life may be precious in his sight, that you may be restored to health and that He will comfort you, and sustain you in your great affliction. Trust, Trust, This is what we need to learn. God is faithful to perform all his promises and more, I know this. I have seen it with my own eyes, and heard with my own ears, and have felt it, and it has comforted me, and if he has been faithful with the dear ones whom he has called to himself, will he not be faithful with us if we are found faithful to him? Yes He will. I wish that it might be best for all for you to come here, I hope that it may, but how little can we tell of the future, or what is best even for ourselves. I trust we may be guided by wisdom from above in all things
With very much love
Samuel

Portsmouth ninth mo 3d 1850
the ashes arrived safe after a passage of eleven days and if the weather continues good I expect to finish unloading the schooner tomorrow I shall do with the proceeds of the cargo as thou directed in thy letter and send thee a certificate of deposit please tell S D Thurston that Capt Joblison? is not going to Philadelphia after eval
From thy friend Levi Almy
Monday morning
Mr Thurston
I rec this letter Sat eve. think it for own interest to get another man for the B.  J M Metcalf thinks that Bliss Blodgett of Bucksport could recommend to us some good man. I know of a man now with Capt Mitchell who I think would do very well. If I can get him, shall we have time to inquire of Mr Blodgett? I shall be up to night or tomorrow
In haste
S.W. Furber

Portsmouth 6 mo 23d 1859
Respected Friend
I recieved thy letter yesterday stating that thou hadst disposed of thy ashes for the present season and that S W Furbur had a cargo to sell I would be very much obliged to thee to say to him that if his ashes are of the same quality of thine we would take his cargo at fourteen cents per bushel and find skow to land them the first of the eighth month would be the most convient time to recieve them if S W Furber concludes to send them please write soon 
From Thy Friend
Levi Almy

Cottage Grove Feb. 26th 1850
Brother Samuel
This with us is the breaking up of a hard winter, our snow is leaving us very fast, will probably disappear entirely in the course of a few days
February has been as pleasant a month as I most ever witnessed, we have not had a single storm of any sort since January, but Dec and January make cold ?, I have done nothing all winter but to get wood, and tend the stable, I have three young calves about four weeks old, and eight[young pigs two weeks old, but have not as yet any young chickens, except my little girls, and they are about as much trouble as there is any need for, they are at this time just breaking prison, the inside of the old cabin had no showers? for them now, Estella is great hand for feeding the calves , and pigs, and is very anxious to undertake the milking, I can hardly get out doors but she must go with me, as I am called away for writings, I shall defer this until some more convenient opportunity

Sunday eve March 3rd
I am getting along very well at ? with my house, but am Somewhat fearful that my means will will give out before I get it entirely compleated, I find as I progress with it that I have to raise my estimate of its cost, I am satisfied now that when compleated it will have cost me $1,000,00 one thousand dollars, but I shall have a good house built in good stile --- It will consist inside of two 15 feet square rooms, one 12 X 15 feet, one tearoom 8 X 10, one buttrey, 6 feet by 8, a cloathes press 3 X 4 feet, and a stair way, a chaimber? 15 X 32 feet, 3 1/2 feet from the chamber? floor? to the plaits? , The outside will  exhibit two frounts? 32 feet each, one of them with a verandah 32 feet by 5, and a fine cellar at an expense of about $150,00 one hundred and fifty dollars, I shall not be able to paint until after I move into it, may paint in the fall
Theodore had a vey good and comfortable house near finished
Mr Haskell had a very good dwelling but not yet everything finished

I wish that when you write again, you would give me and idea of your further plans of operations, I do not suppose that you intend to always labour by the month, if not I suppose you must have some intention of Settling Somewhere, and make you a home
Have you any idea of where you may be one, two, or three years hence, this laboring by the month or year for wages is (to me) an unpleasant business
I believe that every man who can should have a home, and it should be his chief object to make it the abode of content and happiness, a place of happy retreat from the storms, the noise and bustle, the troubles and difficulties, disappointments and temptations of a wicked world, and this may be done by those in very moderate circumstances in life if they have but philosiphy sufficient to confine their wants, within their means for unquestionably, it is not the amount of a persons possessions that produces either riches or happiness, some are richer, some are contented, and happy with $5,00 that others are in the posession of their thousands
Good night

J. Warren Feb 26
Sunday Morning March 9th
I think from father's letters lately that he has come to a determination to come to Minnesota
He talked some of coming out himself in June next, but had not yet determined uppon the matter, thinkes he shall move a year from this spring
We are expecting a large influx of emigration the coming year
What a change has taken place here since I first came into this part of the North west, and the three years to come will produce a greater one,
Our friends here are all in the enjoyment of a usual degree of health
Tender my kind regards to all enquiring friends, as I do the hospitality of my habitation should any of them think of visiting Minnesota
Adieu, your Brother
Warren

Cottage Grove April 10th 1850
Brother Samuel
Yours of March 1st was received on the 8th inst
I am glad to hear that you are in good health and living easy, taking the world cooly, I suppose that ere this reaches you Father will have left for Minnesota, I wrote him about this weeks sience, Soliciting him to bring (in case he comes) eather Mother or Mehitable, and I hope he will consider favorably my request, If mother thinkes that she cannot come I cannot see any reason why Mehitable cannot come out with him, as much now as a year hence
Should father move west I cannot well conclude how you will be able to content yourself within the neighborhood of Milo, I am well aware that it must be a much more severe task to be there left, as it were, alone in the hands of your fathers than it is for one to leave their fathers hands and family and travel nth? a far and distant country and sojourn among strangers entirely

in the latter case, every place, and every Sea? is new, if not interesting, and is calculated in some measure to busey our minds and think draw our thouts from those we may have lately have parted with, but in the former case there is hardley an object uppon which the Eye may rest but what reminds us of those who have departed, departed perhaps never to return, how lonely indeed must the heart be thus situated, If father sells his cottage and it came to be inhabited by strangers I shall never have the most distant desire to ever behold it again, how great the difference between tarrying among strangers in a strange place, and tarrying among strangers in the land of our childhood, the one is endurable, but sometimes pleasant, but the other alas!how sad, who can endure it, But you will not be left amongst strangers, nor without friends, you have a wife a bosom companion, and your wives friends and family, besides undoubtedly many other nearer friends, but never the less you can best feel that the mother who bear you, the father who protects, and supports your youthful days, and the brother, and sister of your child hood, are in a far distant country

Thursday eve the 11th
I wrote last eve untill I had wrought myself into quite a melancholy state of mind and I concluded it would be well to stop and sleep uppon the strength of the matter
I have nothing new of importance to give you at this time
I believe that we are enjoying a usual degree of good health the health of my children is much better this spring than it was in the winter
We had one of the most pleasant Feb I ever witnessed but March was a cold and uncomfortable month and April thus far is backward. I expect to commence sawing next week, expect to put my crop in a cone, shall saw about forty fine acres, do all my work with one span of mules,
I have the carpenter work on my house finished Shall not be able to commence plastering until the last of May
Mr William does the work
S.W. Furber

J Warren April 10
You are mistaken about our Legislature bating themselves a good per diem., the pay of Members is fixed by Congress in the act organizing the territory ($3, per day __________ The extra compensation of the presiding officers of eather branch is however an allowance made by the assembles, and this is customary in all legislative bodys, The pay of a member of Congress is $8, and in the general appropriations bill the sum of $8 is allowed for the presiding officer, making the speakership of the House of Rep in Congress worth $16 per day, a very pretty little sum
S,W, Furber

I called at your house and your wife said you had gone to Frankfurt -- but would do about the Brandywine just as I would think best. Bangor Jany 24 1851
My Dear Sir
Enclosed you have a copy or a partial copy made so far as you may need of my permit to Alfred Cushman and Joseph Cushman. I wish to call your particular attention to it. In the spring I shall come up with Simmons I shall want you to scale what he has left in the woods. In the mean time you will careful what talk you have with them for I have the belief that they will misrepresent anything & everything you may say. They are on there without any legal authority from ? from their course I have no doubt they mean to act in perfect defiance of all law. So be careful to say nothing and their chance of misrepresentation will be lessened. I send you a paper both of which I want you to read and one of them to hand to Bailey. Compare them and see that they are both alike. Retain one in your own hands for a copy   over
[Vertical writing on the left side]: I have made the copy of the permit full

I have written to Francis Wyman in that I cannot allow my Scaler to be insulted while in the discharge of his duty I have heard of the conduct of his brothers in the woods, I want to call to your attention particularly to their case and don't you allow them to beat you in the slightest manner & dont alter your scale on account of it. If they do not cut their logs right you must see the choppers. You asked me in your last letter if I wished you to get an a/e of the Stumpage cut on LR9 or 2 R 9? last summer. I do want you to attend it
A man by the name of Fiske is cutting on the South 1/2 of LR6 or 1 R 6?. It belongs partly to me and I should like to have you attend the scaling.
I am much obliged to you for writing occasionally. Do let me hear from you as often as you can
Truly Yours
Wm H McCulles

I said in the former part of this letter that I shall come up in the Spring with Simmons + shall want you to scale what is left in the woods. I mean what should have been cut according to the strict terms of the permit. Although I say they have no authority to cut in any way still as a precaution I mean that the timber shall be scaled according to the permit
Wm H McCulles

"A message from the heart" say the lips, a message from the heart" what an outrage, what a base libel it is a matter that the heart knows nothing of, in which it has neither part nor lot, still the lips say "from the heart, from the heart," poor heart! if the lips were thy only servant, how severe would be our judgment of thee, how fickle and how varying we should call thee, but thou hast another servant whose report may be relied upon, the Eye, this is ever faithful ever true; never going into raptures on melting into love but with the truth, the loftiest intellect cannot command it, nor heaps of gold bribe it to falsehood, it is ever faithful, giving true account,  The lips speak forth praises to the Most High, and utter curses upon all that is pure and holy. They sing God, holy name and revel in the pollution of all the basest passions, they are venal servants working for the highest bidder,  If for a moment the good within us (and I believe "there is nothing so evil but is?  hath some good") shall prevail and the heart be lifted in gratitude to God and filled with love to man. The lips will be its most ready servant sending forth healing streams  laded with love and sympathy, "A heart that is full of goodness, that loves

and pities that yearns to invest the richest of its mercy in the souls of those that need it - how sweet a tongue hath such a heart! Even its silence is beautiful."   Again  With such views and feelings, how hateful seems the idea, now so lamentably prevalent in some portions of society, of individual right as if whatever affects the one die not equally affect both, as if the heart of one could be touched and not touch the hearts of all who gather around the same hearth stone. Whatever tends to perfect a oneness, or unity of all domestic interists should be cherished as of inestimable value, and whatever would divide those interests and set up the right of one over against the rights of another, should receive instant condemnation
[on side]:
S.W. Furber
St Paul 1857
